Short review:

Great game but has a very big learning curve, like REALLY BIG.

Detailed review:

I love this game, if you like the vibe of it, you will absolutely love it. The problem, as I stated before, is that the learning curve is as exponential as a turbo charged car. When i first played the game, I didn't know much about car stuff, still managed to build the car with tutorials. The hardest part are what I would call "getting started" and "building & tuning" the car.
Every updates have just made the game harder and harder, so the first couple of hours in the game are very tough...
There are few possibilities on what to do at first, I go more on a "speedrun" aproach to it with the moped and few items, but it is probably easier with the tractor (takes more time tho).
That game made me fall in love with Finland aswell, it's the only game that can make me rage quit and still make me launch it again 5-10min after.

Tips:
- Go get the bonus money at the Uncle house (house behind yours)
- Install the driver seat in the car so you can get the uncle's van faster (be carefull to not break the windshield)
- Check if you can spot used pistons (they look more toasted than the others) and buy some new ones at the mechanic shop in Loppe, you better buy a new headgasket
- Your water pump, alternator and starter are gonna break probably soon, so it's something you need to look forward to change
- Same with the fuel pump and perhaps the clutch
- At the teimo shop, buy oil, new oil filter, spark plugs, a box of fuses (very usefull if your fridge fuse breaks), a fan belt, 3 bottles of break fluid, some food
- Put the food in the fridge (except chips)
- If you need to change fuses in the house, first turn off the main voltage or you can get shocked
- Don't answer the phone when it rings only 1 time during thunderstorm

Tarvikkeet: Tarvitset ainakin:  
Käymisastia, johon kansi: (tässä tapauksessa 10L sankko, voidaan myös soveltaa, mutta raaka-ainemäärät huomioitava)
Hiivaa: 2 palaa leivontahiivaa, tai 25g kuivahiivaa. Myös ns. "Super Hiivaa" voidaan käyttää, jolloin noin 1/2 pussia hiivaa ja hiivaravinteita
Sokeria: n. 2kg, mieluiten glukoosia, tai taloussokeria


Seuraavat välineet eivät ole pakollisia, mutta ne helpottavat ja parantavat lopputulosta
Vesilukko: myydään suurissa vähittäistavarakaupoissa ja kotiviinin erikoisliikkeissä (hinta noin 1-2€)
Lappo: myydään yleiskaupoissa/rautakaupoissa, kuten K-Rauta, Tarjoustalo, Halpahalli

Valmistaminen: 

Päivä 1.
1. Ota 10L vetoinen käymisastia, laske sinne hanasta 8L kädenlämpöistä,- eli n. 38°C vettä
2. Lisää veden sekaan sokeri sekoittaen
3. Odota, että vesi on noin 30-34 asteista (palahiiva kuolee 36 asteessa, kuivahiiva kestää 42 astetta, mutta 45 sekin kuolee varmasti)
4. Lisää astiaan hiivat, sekoita
5. Tee astian kanteen yksi reikä, halkaisijaltaan noin 1,5cm (Jos tätä kohtaa ei tehdä, käymisastian sisällä muodostuu noin 80L hiilidioksidia ja muita kaasuja ja astia räjähtää paineen seurauksena) älä tee liian suurta reikää; käyminen on an-aerobinen prosessi, joten liika hapen määrä astian sisällä aiheuttaa etikoitumisen ja kiljun pilaantumisen.
Jos sinulla on vesilukko, kiinnitä se tähän reikään, tiivistä vesilukon ja kannen reijän välinen alue kuuma,- tai pikaliimalla. Kaada vesilukko noin puolilleen vettä.

Nyt odotellaan 7-12 päivää (jos käytit Super Hiivaa, niin 3-7 päivää)
Tällä ajalla voi vaikka kerätä kavereistaan porukan nauttimaan kiljua, sitä päivää varten, kun se valmistuu :).

Päivä 7-12 (tai 3-7).
1. Tähän vaiheeseen päästään, kun vesilukosta ei enään pulputa, kuin pari satunnaista kuplaa minuutissa, tai kannen avattuasi neste on kirkasta ja ei vaahtoa
2. Ota suuri lusikka/kauha, sekä pulloja tai laseja joihin haluat annostella valmiin kiljun
3. Ota lusikalla/kauhalla hyvin varovasti kiljua aluksi pinnasta, sitten keskiväliltä, mutta kun nestettä on enään noin 3cm pohjan korkeudesta, niin et ennään koske siihen, koska se on hiivasakkaa, joka pilaa kiljun maun.
Jos sinulla on lappo:nosta astia varovasti korkeammalle, kuin pullo/lasi mihin aijot kiljun siirtää. Pistä lapon pää astiassa olevan kiljun pinnalle, ota pullo/lasi valmiiksi viereesi, imaise voimakkaasti lapon päästä. Kun teet näin, kiljun pitäisi imeytyä lappoon ja sitten sitten siirrät nopeasti lapon pään pulloon/lasiin. Kiljua alkaa siirtyä nopeasti lapon välillä . Varo ettei käymisastiassa oleva pää missään vaiheessa mene liian lähelle (noin 3cm) lähelle pohjaa, koska muuten sakka sekoittuu kiljun ja joudut odottamaan sen tasaantumista tuskallisen hitaat 5-7 tuntia :S.


Tällä ohjeella saat itsellesi n. 8L kiljua. Tämän kiljun kirkkaus on parhaimmillaan luokkaa 5/10 (kelvollinen)

Valmistusohje
Kuoritaikina:
1½ dl vettä
1 rkl öljyä
3/4 tl suolaa
3 dl ruisjauhoja
1 dl vehnäjauhoja

Täytevaihtoehto 1:
2 ½ dl vettä
2 dl riisiä
7 ½ dl maitoa
1/2 tl suolaa
1 kananmuna

Täytevaihtoehto 2:
8 dl vettä
2 dl riisiä
2 dl (laktoositonta) ruokakermaa 10% tai 15%
1 kananmuna

Täytevaihtoehto 3:

2 dl vettä
2 dl esikypsytettyjä, kokonaisia ohrasuurimoita
1,5 l maitoa
1 tl suolaa
1 kananmuna

Voiteluun: voita sulatettuna ja vettä

Valmista ensin täyte:

Täytevaihtoehto 1 ja 3 valmistaminen:
2. Sekoita kiehuvaan veteen riisi tai ohra ja keitä 10 minuuttia.
3. Lisää maito ja anna puuron kiehua hiljalleen 30 minuuttia välillä pohjaa pitkin sekoittaen. Jätä täyte hautumaan kannen alle 10 minuutiksi.
4. Mausta valmis puuro suolalla ja jäähdytä se.
5. Sekoita jäähtyneeseen puuroon muna.

Täytevaihtoehto 2 valmistaminen:
2. Sekoita kiehuvaan veteen riisi ja keitä noin 30 minuuttia. Sekoita välillä.
3. Lisää joukkoon (laktoositon) ruokakerma ja suola. Anna puuron hautua noin 10 minuuttia.
4. Kaada puuro laakeaan astiaan ja kaada tilkka kylmää vettä päälle, jotta puuron pinnalle ei muodostu kuorta.
5. Sekoita jäähtyneeseen puuroon kananmuna.

Piirakoiden valmistaminen:
1.  Sekoita  kylmään veteen, öljy,  suola ja jauhot puuhaarukalla. Vaivaa taikina sileäksi ja kiinteäksi.
2.  Ripottele pöydälle ruis- ja vehnäjauhoseosta ja kaada taikina jauhojen päälle. Kaulitse taikinasta noin 1/2 cm:n paksuinen levy.
3.  Painele levystä juomalasilla kakkaroita.
4.  Aseta kakkarat kuuden kappaleen pinoihin, etteivät ne kuivu. Peitä pinot muovipussilla tai kulholla.
5.  Kaulitse kakkarat piirakkapulikalla ohuiksi pyöreiksi tai soikeiksi kuoriksi. Lado kuoret päällekkäin ja ripottele ruisjauhoja väliin. Peitä kuoripinot muovipussilla. Täytä kuoret mahdollisimman pian, jotta ne eivät tartu kiinni toisiinsa.
6.  Ota kuoret leivinpöydälle, levitä lusikallinen täytettä kuoren keskelle (1 cm paksuinen kerros täytettä) ja jätä kuoren reunoilta noin 1 cm tyhjää tilaa.
7.  Käännä vastakkaiset reunat täytteen päälle ja rypytä piirakat etusormilla.
8.  Siirrä piirakat uunipellille leivinpaperin päälle.
9. Paista piirakoita 275-300°C lämmössä noin 15 minuuttia.
10. Voitele piirakat  sulatetulla voilla, johon on sekoitettu tilkka vettä.
11. Lado kuumat piirakat kulhoon päällekkäin ja peitä leivinpaperilla ja liinalla. Tarjoile perinteisen tai munattoman munavoin kanssa.

Perinteinen munavoi

4 munaa
2 dl raejuustoa
100 g voita tai margariinia
(4 rkl persiljasilppua)

Laita munat kattilaan kiehuvaan veteen yksitellen ruokalusikkaa apuna käyttäen ja keitä 8 minuuttia.
Nosta keitetyt munat joksikin aikaan kylmään veteen, jolloin kuori irtoaa helpommin.
Kun kananmunat ovat jäähtyneet, kuori ne.
Laita kananmunat isolle lautaselle ja hienonna ne haarukalla tai käytä munaleikkuria.
Sekoita joukkoon raejuusto ja huoneenlämpöinen, pehmeä rasva.
Jos haluat, voit lisätä päälle hienonnettua persiljaa.
Munaton munavoi

1 tlk esikypsytettyjä kikherneitä
250 g kiinteää tofua
150 g margariinia
1 tl suolaa

1 dl persiljaa ja 1 chili

Valuta ja huuhtele kikherneet. Rouhi kikherneet haarukalla karkeaksi.
Murenna tofu.
Sekoita kikherne- ja tofumuru sekä margariini. Mausta suolalla.
Hienonna persilja ja sekoita joukkoon. Hienonna myös puolet chilistä ja sekoita joukkoon. Koristele chiliviipaleilla.

Truly a purposefully irritating experience.
Everything will kill you.
You cannot shave time off of anything.
You have to drive a moped ten minutes to town to buy one thing and drive it back for ten more minutes.
If you die you take the bus for fifteen minutes back to an intersection kind of close to where you died and walk.
Walking is crawling.
You can only hold one thing at a time.
You can drop items through the map.
You can die by crouching near parked cars.
You have a very limited time frame to do everything.
Pressing the wrong button at the wrong time like "f" instead of "g" is completely devastating.
Everything drives like hot trash.
You will do very mundane things tens of times before you are even close to "driving your car".
Drive to town for gas, batteries, food, fuses, beer, more batteries, more gas, an alternator belt, more beer.
Drive them back one at a time.
Getting to the car solves it all because you now have a trunk. Then there is nothing really left to do and the car drives like such hot ass, basically it's a ton of work and upkeep before you can drive around this ugly landscape in a nicer car.
This game is built specifically to annoy you.
I got what I expected, and was not disappointed.

MSC, if you're into cars, especially building them, you'll love this game! MSC is basically a survival game where you get to build your car, the Satsuma, from the ground up! It's a unique experience! You get jobs to make some money, and you can also race your project car when it's done, winning trophies, etc. The downside, though, is that the game is buggy, hence it's in its development stage. But it won't really ruin the experience for you. Good luck! Enjoy the game!

game is mediocre tbh. The leaning system is horrifically disorienting, all the nut/bolt heads have NO SENSE of consistency across the game. One bolt will LOOK massive, like a size 15, and another will look tiny, like a size 7, and then they're both size 11 for whatever reason. Leads to a ton of unnecessary trips to and from the toolkit and it gets extremely old extremely fast. Also why the f**k is scroll wheel the only option to fasten a bolt/nut? Also the audio? Loud sounds like the engine absolute buttf**k your ears and make it impossible to hear important, but quieter sounds in the car.

Another part of this game that annoys me is how difficult it is to just place shit on the car. You are left essentially trying to line up pixels so you can get the little check-mark just to accidentally bump the car and have the dogs**t physics send you skyward. Was looking for a decently in-depth but still relaxing and enjoyable driving/mechanic game, looks like I'll keep looking.

On one hand, building the car is extremely fun and possibly the most indepth I've ever seen, and then on the other, everything else sucks. The raw idea of the game is fantastic, a life simulator where you gotta build a project car and modify it as you please, but this game is so buggy,  its been years its on early-access, plus nearly everything seems to be specifically made to screw you over. No fun is allowed, you will waste a >LOT< of time in this game, you will be forced to reset saves, you will die because a bee crashed on you while you were driving, people will touch your car while you're parked, die, and you will go to jail for that (jail time if often ridiculous like 10 irl hours, yes, 10 irl hours.), every trip to the city will take a ridiculously long time because the only convenience store HAD to be on the other side of the map, the driving physics are very meh and if you decide to walk anywhere at all, good luck, everything is extremely far apart, the map is pretty much empty and your character dies of thirst comically fast when walking unless you bring a whole pack of beers with you

Driving with a keyboard sucks, obviously, but it feels like the game was not made for a steering wheel either. Setting one up is pain, the customization and tweaking is extremely limited and buggy, it seems like the only way to get a wheel working decently is via mods.

I wanna play this game because its premise is fantastic, but everytime I do its mostly just frustrating simply because the devs decided to design the game to be frustrating, to be full of RNG and deliberate design choices that makes your life hell.

could be a 10/10, but is a solid 4/10

"My Summer Car" isn't your typical gaming experience, and that's precisely what makes it shine. If you're a die-hard automotive enthusiast or enjoy challenging simulations, this game is a hidden gem on the Steam platform.

Prepare to dive headfirst into the Finnish countryside of the 1990s, armed with little more than a rusty car and a basic set of tools. The game's unique selling point lies in its detailed and realistic car building and maintenance simulation. Every bolt, screw, and component matters as you meticulously piece together your vehicle from scratch. It's a refreshing departure from the hand-holding prevalent in many games today.

The open-world environment adds an extra layer to the experience. Beyond the garage, you can explore the charming countryside, engage in odd jobs, and interact with eccentric NPCs. However, be ready for the survival aspect, as hunger, thirst, and the possibility of deadly car accidents add an intriguing challenge to the mix.

While the graphics might not appeal to everyone with their intentionally dated, low-polygon style, they contribute to the game's nostalgic atmosphere. The visuals, coupled with the quirky Finnish humor, create a unique ambiance that sets "My Summer Car" apart.

Buckle up for a steep learning curve; this game doesn't hold your hand. Understanding the intricacies of each car part and the overall mechanics takes time and patience. Yet, for those willing to invest in the learning process, the sense of accomplishment when your hand-built car roars to life is immensely satisfying.

"My Summer Car" might not cater to everyone's taste, but for those seeking an unconventional, challenging, and immersive experience, it's a must-try. It's a testament to indie game development, offering something truly distinct in the vast landscape of Steam titles. So, if you're up for a one-of-a-kind journey into car-building realism with a touch of Finnish eccentricity, "My Summer Car" is well worth adding to your Steam library.

Most of my reviews are satirical, but I won't be fooling around regarding this game's review.

I have been playing this game for years now - I didn't buy it on Steam first, but now that I have the money I decided to buy it, and I'll put more hours into this game than I originally had.
This game is hard - sometimes irritating, spontaneously filled with mistakes, but despite all of this it really stuck with me. Even though I had difficulties building the car at first, and after dying multiple times due to the game's stupidity, I still enjoy this game (sometimes). It has a very nice mood - building your car in the finnish countryside, the life survival aspect of the game really puts you in the role of a finnish car obsessed teenager in the mid '90s. Really reminds me of my home country, even though the fact that I wasn't alive during that time! 

Most of the stuff that I've mentioned here you can probably find in other, way more popular reviews too, but I don't really care, I had to say this. In summarisation: this game is a masterpiece.

The game was recommended to me while I was recovering from my surgery - perfect excuse to dive into something that looks like Maluch Racer Simulator and not being called a weirdo for building some wonky car that is being held up entirely by bolts, right? I was initially warned that the game has horror elements, so upon launching the game I proceeded with caution. 90's Finnish family house threateningly welcomed me, with it's purposefully unpolished graphics. Then I took a look around and noticed the Satsuma itself, in front of the garage. In the garage I've realized what could be the horror of this game - hundreds of little parts that I had to assemble to make the car run, with my zero knowledge of the car and engine anatomy, apart from lights, doors, hood, wheels and windshield.

 It quickly turned out that the game was pretty unforgiving. First of all, you have needs that you have to take care of: thirst, hunger, stress, fatigue, URINE (you click P to relieve yourself, how cool is that?) and so on and so on. If full, few of those will get you killed. Your character on top of that is slow as fuck, like he never ran more than 100 meters at the time, so even though he has unlimited stamina, you will need some kind of vehicle. Fortunately, before you assemble Satsuma you have few options to choose from: the boat, which of course you can only use to get around on the lake, Kekmet tractor that is fuel inefficient and is pretty slow and finally, Jonez scooter, which I chose for my temporary mode of transportation. On my way to the shop I was jumpscared by the dirtroads' green menace, almost killed on the highway by ignorant drivers, but finally arrived just fine. After the visit in the shop to buy sasuages and frozen pizza, the little money I had at the start of the game quickly depleted, putting me in the position of looking for the job. 
 
 See, this game is not only about driving vehicles, it's more of a Finnish countryside in the 90's simulator, so with that you can pick strawberries, deliver firewood or empty sewage. There are also few other jobs that you should discover yourself, I'll just recommend you to go pick strawberries first for good lubrication into how this game makes you earn money and generally how it rewards you for doing something (note, it's a mental battle).

 As you may have already noticed, I have 200 hours into this game and I truly love it. The point of this game is to make you suffer, but you want to suffer with it. You will get through the painful process of picking strawberries, you will get used to Pena jumpscares, you will finally build and run the satsuma (I've only managed to do this after 50 FRICKING HOURSE OF PLAYING!) and then you will even attempt to participate in the rally or even finish the game's plot (yes, there is one)

 You will have fun and you will cry.

My Summer Car is a great game with a great concept. Too bad that concept is impossible to accomplish.

The concept is great, build a car, make money on the side, and do whatever the hell you want to do! But- there are so many bugs that get in the way of such a great game, it pains me to give a negative review. I've had a lot of fun, and put a lot of hours into this game. But the bugs are just too much. I enjoy the occasional non-game breaking bug. I think they can be hilarious. Like glitching into your car, and being launched 50 feet into the air, or, well that's really the only bug in the game that isn't infuriating. Here is a list of some of the painful bugs I've run into:

Moped disappeared, what can you do about it? Shit if I know.

Paying for Fleetari (The Mechanic) to do work on your car, get home, answer the phone "Fleetari here, your car is done." Drive back, no work has been done. Wait two or three ingame days. No work has been done.

Getting ran over by the yellow Assho-I mean racer. Not really a big deal. Load the game back up (after saving when I died) And I load back on a previous save.

Parts dissapearing. Hooked up my exhaust last minute before sending it off to the shop, get back, Fleetari has punished me for stealing his car, by dumping my car in the swamp, aaaand snatching my exhast pipe.

Sewage truck stuck? Oh well. Your bitch arms can't push it, Quit without saving.

Ordered a package, paid for it, turned around to pick it up. No package. 

These things really suck. But would I pay for the game again, and play it all over? Yep. It really has a certain charm about it. It has a lot of fun aspects to it. Like giving the finger to that God Da-I mean yellow racer. Pumping and pouring sewage wherever you please. And tuning the car to your specific specifications. 

It really pains me to give this a negative review, especially it being an early access game. Because it's an early access game. But I'd suggest holding off for a little bit until some of these bugs are sorted out. 

Right now, I'd give it a 6/10. If you can look past the game breaking bugs, Which is difficult, I'd give it a hefty 8.5/10, because it still is a blast to play. And once these bugs are sorted out, I will happily give this game a positive review, because I can tell the game has taken work, and it is a really great game, deep down.

EDIT: I get it now. It all makes sense. I'm at peace with My Summer Car

My Summer Car is a unique and unconventional indie game that immerses players in the wild world of building and maintaining a car in the Finnish countryside. Developed by Amistech Games, this title offers a blend of simulation, survival, and open-world exploration. Released in 2016, it has garnered a dedicated fanbase due to its realism and unapologetically challenging gameplay.

At first glance, My Summer Car may seem like a simple car-building simulator, but it quickly becomes apparent that the game is much more than that. The experience begins with the player inheriting a decrepit Satsuma, a fictional Finnish car, and the task of bringing it to life. From assembling the engine to adjusting the suspension, every detail of the car demands attention, making it a gearhead's dream.

The game's setting, a rural Finnish village in the 1990s, contributes to its distinct charm. The open-world environment is vast and filled with quirky characters, each with their own peculiarities. While the graphics may not be cutting-edge, the attention to detail in the surroundings and the realistic day-night cycle create an immersive atmosphere.

Survival elements add an unexpected layer of complexity. The player needs to eat, drink, and sleep to stay alive. Balancing these basic needs while fixing the car can be challenging, creating a sense of urgency and forcing players to strategize their time effectively.

One of the standout features of My Summer Car is its learning curve. With minimal in-game tutorials, players must figure out the mechanics, tools, and car parts on their own. While this can be frustrating for newcomers, it rewards perseverance and patience. However, the lack of guidance may be a turn-off for players seeking a more casual gaming experience.

The game's humor is another notable aspect. The eccentric characters and unpredictable events inject a healthy dose of comedy into the gameplay. From navigating the perils of Finnish bureaucracy to unexpected encounters with drunk NPCs, the absurdity adds a layer of unpredictability that keeps the experience fresh.

However, My Summer Car is not without its flaws. Bugs and glitches are prevalent, and the game can be unforgiving, leading to moments of frustration. Some players may find the lack of clear objectives and structure to be a drawback, as the game relies heavily on player-initiated goals.

In conclusion, My Summer Car is a unique and challenging experience that caters to a specific audience. It's a love letter to automotive enthusiasts and those seeking an unconventional open-world adventure. The game's realism, combined with its eccentric charm, creates a memorable and unpredictable journey. However, its steep learning curve and technical issues may deter more casual gamers. If you're willing to embrace chaos, endure setbacks, and revel in the absurd, My Summer Car offers a truly one-of-a-kind gaming experience.

I personally can't recommend the game in its current state. Its janky and some people love that, hell I love playing "The Long Drive" but this game is a joke in comparison.

Multiple ways to be softlocked. How do you fix things? Start over or install mods which is super lame. 

I love tedious games I have several of those types of games in my inventory. I spent most of time putting together the car and didn't have too much of a problem but a couple things happened. Followed several guides exactly, car doesn't start. So I learned that the starter and the battery I started with were broken with no fix.

Can't buy a new one because the uncle literally never spawned even after checking about every in game hour. I got him to spawn once when I started the game... So unable to buy new parts. Couldn't earn money to live because you're dependent on one game mechanic that is basically a soft-lock. Can't recommend it. There's a lot of joke reviews with people with less than a few hours and I think a lot of people truly play it for the meme vs actually playing it to enjoy the core mechanics.

As a suggestion just to make sure you get a refund back. Really pour into the core mechanic of putting together the car in a couple of hours and truly look into the experience. If it's not working for you delete the game and get a refund. Don't do what I did and try to just see it out with the hope that the game might eventually work out.

Stared Playing, Fixed up Satsuma to an 8 Year Old Tutorial, Car Blew Up, Started Again, Fixed up Car to an Updated Tutorial, Got Engine Running, Pulled out Garage, Blew up Tire. At first it really looked like a game I might enjoy, but after trying it out, I'm afraid it needs some more time in the oven, if that's going to fix it at all.

I understand this is still in early access, but nevertheless at this moment I cannot recommend this.

The game is far too janky. And I'm not talking only about the physics - everything about it, the mechanics, the way things handle, the gameplay, seem to be improvised and held together by duct tape.

Nothing is intuitive. There is no information provided on anything - no tutorial, not even a single tip on screen to explain how anything works. One of the first things I did was having to comb through the 3 separate pages of keyboard control binds in order to figure out how to even play (which is not a good sign for [i]any[/i] game that isn't a hardcore flight simulator), and after 30 minutes of trying to figure out how to install car parts in the vehicle you start with, I had to consult google to find out the very basics of the game. Yeah, it's one of those games which are unplayable (at least at first) without online guides and/or wiki.

Nothing is explained. Small example - in order to assemble car parts, you need to use tools. How, you may ask? Well, assuming you know which one to use to begin with, you need to find a tool case in the garage. Then know that you need to open the tool case (not with the left click but with the "F" key), then press 2 to go into "tool mode", and finally click on the screwdriver to take it out. There is no information about it in the game and you need to look it up online.

Interactable items are often very picky about how you aim at them, sometimes requiring a very specific angle and distance in order for the cursor to recognize them as something that can be picked up or used.

Another example of clunkiness is driving vehicles. There is a moped outside the house, so I've tried to drive it - another task that needs consulting an online tutorial. You would think that you just click it to sit on it and start driving... but nope. You need to first carefully position yourself over the bike - during which your character sometimes jitters chaotically because of janky physics (occasionally this may topple the bike over), and only then press return key to "Enter Driving Mode". Oh, and you also need to know that in order to start it, you need to open the fuel tap located low on the left side, and only then click repeatedly on the jumpstart crank. Of course, none of this is explained in game.

In short, very promising concept, got my hopes up because the idea of satiric role playing as a finnish beer-chugging, cigarette smoking teen assembling and driving an unlicensed car hobbled together in a garage seems very entertaining, but the execution is poor, too crude, too unfinished, and very much not accessible to a new player.

My Summer Car: Where fixing a virtual car is more stressful than a real-life oil change. In this game, you'll learn that assembling a vehicle requires more patience than a saint and more swear words than a sailor. From dodging drunk-driving fines to avoiding moose collisions, it's a simulation of the Finnish countryside that turns every road trip into a comedic adventure. Just remember, in My Summer Car, the struggle is not just real – it's hilariously frustrating.

What a unique and interesting game MSC is.  Now I understand why this game was so popular for so long.  The game is a lot of fun once you get the hang of the janky physics and controls and it can also be notoriously difficult and frustrating to learn if you don't know what to do starting out.  Thankfully, there are good guides to tell you everything you need to know.  The Steam discussion board is still going pretty strong even now and there's some good guides in the MSC Steam Community and the game wiki that can also help a lot here:

https://my-summer-car.fandom.com/wiki/My_Summer_Car_Wiki

You start out in your house and you need to build an old car (the game's main objective if there is one) starting with some basic tools, a chassis and a hundred different parts laying around your garage (some you need to buy from the store) but you also need to learn to survive hunger, thirst, etc.  All the places you need to go in game are scattered all over a large area requiring lots of driving to get there and there is no map to show where you are.  There is one hanging on the wall in your house you can study you can't take it with you so you need to learn to navigate the roads and figure out where you're going by memorizing the terrain & buildings visually.  You can't tell time except by trying to determine the position of the sun (there is a way to get a watch eventually though).  You need to know the time because stores and events are time dependent.  In the country, stores and businesses close very early.

There are jobs you can do to make money like pumping sewage with a poop truck for people and there are events like rallys you can participate in.  There is no saving except in your toilet or if you find an outhouse.  You can even go to jail for various reasons which is extremely boring, there's no way to skip time in jail so you just have to sit there and wait (like in real life!).  The game is basically like living the life of a poor country boy in a very sparsely populated area, building an old car and go driving it around doing stupid things.  I grew up in such a town in th US and the similarities is amazing.  The developer hit the mood just right.  The Finnish are not so different from us in the US.

I'm glad I bought this game finally and I can easily recommend it.

This game is a damn joke.  I spent my entire play session with it questioning if I had outright been scammed into some sort of crypto mining scam as it completely SLAUGHTERED my machine's resources while being the only thing open beyond discord (3070 Ti, Ryzen 7 5700x, 48GB of RAM).  

The game itself feels like it was created by a 14 year old.  Needlessly crude humor, borderline imbecilic gameplay and functionality, and a community that genuinely feels like they live at the compound in Waco, TX.  There is a nugget of a potentially good game hidden somewhere deep within this disaster but it's not worth wading through the garbage to find it.

I do NOT recommend this game.  In fact I'd like to make a plea to steam to remove it because it is JUST. THAT. BAD.  If you bought it and it's still in the refund period, do yourself a favor!

Really great sim game that's less "car rebuilding sim" and more "Finnish person sim". At times VERY frustrating or difficult, but this adds to the charm of it all. There's something special about this one that I can't really describe. Highly recommended.

POSITIVES:
- Rebuild the car. As in all of it. The sheer scope of the car rebuilding is mind boggling. You have to torque stuff properly. You need to manually do a wheel alignment. You have to adjust your air/fuel ratio. Forget a piece in the engine, and well, maybe it will run for a bit. And then suddenly explode. Incredibly in-depth and surprisingly realistic/accurate as well!
- Get drunk, punch the car and swear at it. Don't bathe for a week. Use your parent's bedroom as the designated pissing room. Brew moonshine, then sell it while driving blind in your tractor with Viper playing on your boombox. There is so much goofy crap to do in this game and you will be discovering new activities and oddities for hours.
- Charming art style. Let me be honest: this game looks like ass. But a what a wonderful piece of ass it is. Character models look iconic. Satisfyingly janky animations. Lots of jaggy polygons and wonky textures. But it genuinely works so well with the game's humour.
- Huge modding community filled with tons of quality tweaks, new vehicles, weird things and enhancements. I highly recommend the body pillow mod and the one that adds Maxwell the cat.
NEGATIVES:
- This game is really ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ HARD. I found Elden Ring an easier game than this. Unless you want to make tons of run breaking mistakes or literally sitting in prison for maybe real life days at a time, you'll probably be following a guide or two. Personally I dont think there's much shame in checking the wiki occasionally. This game is very unforgiving when it comes to mistakes. It will PUNISH you. It will make you regret what you did. Whether or not this is a negative is up to you, but be warned!
- There's bugs sometimes. Game does weird ♥♥♥♥ or crashes, not that often though. Really I can't think of many negatives for this game. It's really really good and worth its full price.

Cars

Years into the future this will be a time capsule of a bygone era. Not the era of Finland 1995 alone, but an era of cars, drugs, poverty, economic loss, and most importantly a sense of freedom in crimes against our governments. This game will do anything it can to keep you down, you will earn almost everything the hard way. When you finally get away with crimes, it's true joy. You genuinely defeated a system fully designed against you. That is My Summer Car. This game best represents my childhood in poverty, Appalachia. (Except my dad bought a Subaru instead of this sh*tsuma)

After about 70 hours of pure pain of gameplay I finally managed to not only start the car but also get it to drive well without stalling. I had 0 knowledge about cars prior to this. This game is a real journey.

Has amazing atmosphere that I think mainly scandinavians, eastern europeans and people living in small towns in their late 20s+ would appreciate. It creates scenarios that just feel strangely nostalgic.

Overall the gameplay sometimes feels like an Ikea furniture, it's shit garbage but you are building something yourself so it feels good and so then it becomes good. The driving however feels great, it's some stuff around it that's janky shit. At times it makes me want to gouge my eyes out but it just feels so satisfying and rewarding to play I just want to continue.

I know the game from all the YouTube videos and I really love the idea of it and the gameplay and content looks cool, but the controls are way too complex in my opinion and the game doesn't tell you what to do at the start. I know, you're free to do whatever you desire, but for people who have never played it before are thrown right into the game with no explanation on what to do or what you *could* do. 
I tried assembling the engine but it wouldn't let me install the main bearing caps, but the game wouldn't let me. My guess is that the bearings itself were missing and I had to buy some, so I wanted to check the town's store. There is a bike next to the garage, but the engine didn't crank. No idea why, didn't see a battery and the car battery didn't fit (duh). I also failed using the fuel canister. Also the sound of flies or mosquitos were really annyoing, had to google how I can get rid of them because as again, the game won't tell you anything.
I requested a refund to get another game, but I would really like to give this game another try in the future, hopefully with a tutorial and maybe even better controls!

The Ultimate Finnish Life Simulator.
This game doesnt hold your hand,rather than that,it pushes you, like you are running,or in this case,driving for your life.
In a way or another,thats what you do.
Before building the car, you need to go to the shop,buy stuff that is necessary for you and the car.
You have to check either you got or not the bills.
If yes, pay them, cause if you dont, the electricity stops, and the food rots, and you starve, and you die.
This game is beautiful in its complicated way.

As of my 45 hours in this game, i found myself dying 2 times, first by thinking i can push the boat towards the city (in the lake) and drowning, and second time rolling with the van.

Its funny at first, i personally got very happy thinking about the adventures this game will bring me.
Reality is i didnt even get to drive the car, only a little bit toward the garbage dumping place and that was when i built the car with MSCEditor.

After the 1st death,it was like the fun went away.
I knew i had to spend another day to build a car,this time i also needed a whole in-game day to get the wheels.

The last time i manually built the car was exactly after the 2nd death, i speedran the whole built, and finished it in some hours.
I even painted the car black, as i knew i would like it.
I started the car, waited, and then the engine came off.
I tried another time, on another save, the same exact outcome.

I was frustrated, to say the least, hating the game from the depths of my heart (even if it wasnt its fault, but rather mine).

And then,once again, i decided i wanted to build it again.

And maybe this is the beauty of My Summer Car? The stress, frustration, anger and i dont know what else will pay the player with the satsuma, a reward, almost as if saying "You didnt give up? Here's something to make you give up."


However, the game itself is...well...kind of too rough, either you play with permadeath or not, you still lose, the moment you die, the game saves, no matter what.
Its up to you either you want to start over again,or maybe spend some more hours searching for a fucking piece from the car.

But i suppose thats how you play the game, from the start to finish, an unforgiving road of obstacles that might, or might not, reward you with beautiful memories and fun.


This game is not for everybody.


If there was a way to describe this game, i think it would be that you are not the only idiot in town.

My Summer Car was a great game; the original gameplay mechanics and atmosphere blended seamlessly, and considering the number of hours I spent with the game, I truly enjoyed it. Unfortunately, as of today, in my opinion, the game has become overly complicated and off-putting for both new and returning players. In my view, the 2016/2017 versions of the game were the best and, interestingly, more vibrant.

The game wasn't artificially made more difficult by hiding crucial parts needed for the car in those earlier versions. However, newer releases have somehow disrupted the NPC system, causing many NPCs to appear very rarely or not at all compared to the 2016/2017 versions.

In summary, My Summer Car is a great game that, in my opinion, has been ruined by unnecessary complications and a lack of valuable updates. For those interested, I recommend playing the older versions, which can be downloaded through the console built into the Steam client (after purchasing the game).

Well where should I start?

Most people dont like the game because its "too hard" which is a fair point. Because My Summer Car isnt a game for everybody. And it's not meant to be for everyone. The style of gameplay, the mechanics and the difficulty can not be ""enjoyed"" by your typcial gamer. But in my opinion that is one of the most integral parts of the game. Because the game isnt made for everyone its has a rather not too big not too small comunity. The community of this game is like a small cult-following of some sort. The modding and the YouTube community around it always produces new content to be consumed and enjoyed. The modding community is can be rather menacing to say the least. Also because the community is always open to new players you can find a tutorial for almost everything in the game. It might be for mods, or vanilla stuff. 

As I said, the game is not for everyone. You should get this game if you have basic knowlegde on how engines and car systems work. Also you should be always ready for the worst case scenario. You should always have a plan B. It might be too hard on a average person for the first time. So if you want to buy and play this game, dont expect it to be easy. You should learn to have fun from suffering. 

If you coulndt keep up with the game, or if its not for your taste, PLEASE dont write bad reviews full like "tOO hArd 0/10 dOnt bUy iT iTs a wAsTe of mOney" because you might actually scare of people who might enjoy the game. When you play the game and write a review remember that MSC is not for everyone. And if its not for you it doesnt mean its a bad game.

This game is so damn frustrating. Not because it gives you almost no help or because you have to pixel hunt screws into their threads but because it will take everything from you. The idea is that it takes a long time to do things and that's why you need a car to speed things up, but the game will crash or glitch or not tell you you need to save and ruin all the progress you made on its long, long days. It's very cool. If you have a mechanical mind or interest in doing small things like pulling the string on a motor to start it it's great. And honestly really charming despite some pretty dated humor. I've tried rebuilding my car three times after losing it to bugs and I'm done. I recommend it but just know that you may need mods to help with the save/ item loss issues and that it may still fuck up your game anyways. FUCK. I'm going to try again anyways. This is the best game I have bought this whole year! It's so fun! I will probably have multiple hundred hours in just a couple of weeks in this game.
But some things are a broken or hard to do or understand in the beginning. For example, it's very hard to hit the water on the burner in the sauna. It took me an hour of frustration until I realized that if you sit on the bench in front of the burner it's much easier to hit it. The motorbike is also very hard and unpredictable to drive. Overall it needs a lot of work, but when it's released it will be on my top 10 games list for sure.

Edit: After playing it for a while, I still agree on how fun it is, but the game has the worst driving physics and Force Feedback of any game I have ever played. And I have played many games with driving. The game is still in early access and I really really hope that they fix that, but seeing as the game is 8 years old but still is very broken, has very bad force feedback and driving physics and pretty bad graphics, I'm not even sure if it's still in developement

Recommended for anyone who likes cars, mechanical tinkering or has a case of 90s nostalgia.

My Summer Car is an utterly amazing game. Survive in 1995 Finland, earning money through odd jobs, spend it on alcohol, food and, obviously, car parts. Restore your father's 70s compact car, take it to rally or to race, or just about run your everyday errands in it.

The graphics look a bit PS2-ish and old at first glance, but playing the game that is quickly forgotten, as even visually it makes up for that with a good attention to detail, as well as the way it kind of fits the faux-retro vibe and 90s theme.
The gameplay is quite open and free, but the same attention to detail is what makes it stand out among 'open world survival' games. The titular car is modelled well, of course, and within hours you will know all the parts, bolts and bits of its engine as you assemble, repair and diagnose it. Everyone who knows their way around an engine is a bit at the advantage here, but frankly, those who don't could learn a thing or two here.

The 'proper' way to play My Summer Car of course is with permadeath, where you start entirely over when you die. I am convinced this game has done more for seatbelt awareness than decades of PSAs ever could.

My Summer Car offers an immersive and unique Finnish living experience that goes beyond the typical boundaries of a video game. The open-world simulation allows players to dive into the intricacies of rural Finnish life, blending a mix of mundane tasks and thrilling adventures. From building your own car, the iconic Satsuma, to leisurely drives around the map or participating in intense races, the game offers a diverse range of activities.


Pros:

Realistic Simulation: My Summer Car excels in its realistic simulation of daily life in rural Finland. From chopping wood to purchasing groceries, the game captures the essence of the mundane yet essential tasks that make up everyday living.

Vehicle Customization: The highlight of the game is the ability to build and customize your own car, the Satsuma. The intricate process involves assembling each part, fine-tuning the engine, and ensuring the vehicle is roadworthy, providing a sense of accomplishment.

Open World Exploration: The game features an expansive open world that encourages exploration. Whether it's driving through picturesque landscapes or relaxing at a cottage by the lake, the variety of environments adds depth to the overall experience.

Realistic Driving Physics: My Summer Car boasts realistic driving physics, enhancing the challenge and satisfaction of navigating the roads. From the handling of the Satsuma to the nuances of different terrains, the driving experience feels authentic.

Controller and Steering Wheel Support: The inclusion of support for basic controllers and steering wheels enhances the gameplay experience, allowing players to choose their preferred input method for a more immersive feel.


Cons:

Steep Learning Curve: The game has a steep learning curve, especially for players unfamiliar with automotive mechanics. The detailed process of building and maintaining the Satsuma may be overwhelming for some, requiring patience and perseverance.

Lack of Tutorials: While the realism is a strong point, the game could benefit from more comprehensive tutorials or guides to assist players in understanding the various mechanics and activities. Some may find themselves lost without sufficient guidance.

Occasional Bugs and Glitches: Like many simulation games, My Summer Car is not without its share of bugs and glitches. While updates aim to address these issues, occasional frustrations may arise from unexpected in-game occurrences.


Final Summary:

My Summer Car offers a unique and immersive simulation experience that captures the essence of Finnish rural life. With its realistic tasks, vehicle customization, and expansive open world, the game provides a rich and engaging environment for players. Despite a steep learning curve and occasional technical hiccups, the overall experience is rewarding for those who appreciate attention to detail and a deep sense of realism in their gaming adventures. Whether you're a fan of automotive simulations or seeking a departure from traditional game genres, My Summer Car delivers a distinctive and memorable gameplay experience.

My Summer Car is like your average survival game, but with a twist. You make money to build your Satsuma from the ground up. Imagine a mix between a survival game and Car Mechanic Simulator. Not only do you have to build and upgrade your Satsuma, but you must also take care of your character by keeping factors like; Thirst, Hunger, Stress, Fatigue and Dirtiness in mind. If not, your character's health will slowly deplete until you die. The challenge with My Summer Car is that it is a perma-death game. You die, you lose everything. (Though perma-death can be turned off in the main menu at the start of the game)

What also keeps this game challenging is the fact that when you build your car, every single screw and bolt must be torqued and well adjusted, (Ex: You must adjust each of the engine's valves one by one) and every single part is prone to breaking at random. To me, it's the total randomness that keeps the game fun.

 While some people will say My Summer Car is a tedious and over-complicated game, others will argue that it's what makes it fun. In my personal opinion, My Summer Car is well worth the price, considering there are tons of fan-made mods available if the game ever finds itself to be too boring or challenging for you. You can really make this game what you want it to be, though the vanilla experience is also very fun once you get things up and going. 

If you're looking for a realistic, yet humorous car-building game that never gets boring due to all the curve-balls it throws at you, My Summer Car is the perfect game for you.

This game was great in 2017 / 2018. But a number of patches and updates since then have taken all the fun out of it. While the game has always been trying to 'troll' you; it used to be balanced - you could survive and thrive in the game if you knew the pitfalls. Now, EVERYTHING you do in the game appears to have negative affects. Take the Johnny ES bike for example; it's terrible mode of transport now made worse by the fact that you are guaranteed to fall off at least every minute. Difficulty and challenge is one thing, but this masochistic game is quite another.

If you like being mentally anguished, frustrated and angered, you'll love this game.

EDIT: December 2023

I decided to give the game another go as I wanted to re-setup my old driving hardware, which works great with this game once you've fiddled a bit. I spent several hours building the perfect Satsuma, then on the very first drive got it wrapped around the train. That was funny for all of 5 seconds, when I realised that the game defaulted to Permadeath mode. But you know what? I'm just about to start it all again. Saatana!

A Finnish cultural gem, "My Summer Car" is a surprisingly deep experience wrapped in an unconventional aesthetic. Despite its apparent "ugliness," the game's mechanics are intricate, with every scuff contributing to a richly developed world. The attention to detail extends to realistic simulations of wear and tear, as well as fluid leaks in the car. Regular updates from the dedicated single developer bring appreciated additions and crucial improvements. The vibrant modding community adds a plethora of flavors and customization to enhance your gaming experience. However, the game falters in its repetitive nature, especially concerning jobs and tasks, and it presents a steep learning curve for newcomers. In conclusion, it offers a warm and engaging experience, meriting a 7/10 with limitless replayability.

A few years back, I tried out My Summer Car, got frustrated by the difficulty and lack of any form of tutorial, left a bad review, and refunded it. A few weeks back, I finally decided to try it again, and definitely had a much better time of things.

While the game has more than its fair share of bugs and annoying features, the issues are overshadowed by the fun of taking a pile of parts and turning it into a rally machine, and I highly recommend it.

Everything 100% manual, you need to build the car yourself and everything in this game hates you, from your car randomly exploding because of overheating or just breaking down because one of the pistons decided staying in the engine was too much work, but I now know every part of a car and how/what makes it work and how to drive in real life, but with almost 200 hours in and I still havent passed inspection or gotten into the rally yet.

This game really tests your patience, but is 100% worth it.

A Rollercoaster of Emotions with My Summer Car!

Oh, My Summer Car, you magnificent, infuriating beast of a game! It's like a love-hate relationship that keeps me coming back for more punishment and joy.

Let's start with the love: The attention to detail is nothing short of mind-blowing. From building your own car piece by piece to the immersive open-world environment, it's a car enthusiast's dream come true. The satirical humor and quirky characters add a unique charm that makes every moment memorable.

But oh, the hate: The unforgiving mechanics and the brutal learning curve can make you question your life choices. One minute you're tightening a bolt with a sense of accomplishment, and the next, you're stuck in the middle of nowhere, cursing the Finnish countryside and wondering why you ever thought building a car from scratch was a good idea.

The permadeath feature? It's both a blessing and a curse. The sense of danger and consequence keeps you on your toes, but losing hours of progress due to a silly mistake can be soul-crushing.

And let's not forget the notorious AI drivers – they're either your best friends or your worst enemies. One moment, they're offering a friendly ride, and the next, they're causing chaos on the road like it's a demolition derby.

In conclusion, My Summer Car is a masterpiece that tests your patience, resilience, and sanity. It's a wild ride that will have you laughing, crying, and questioning your life choices in equal measure. Love it or hate it, you can't deny its unique charm and the satisfaction that comes with conquering its challenges. Now, if you'll excuse me, I need to go rage-quit and then come back for more punishment – because, deep down, I can't resist the allure of My Summer Car's twisted embrace. Ps I hacked up the neighbors with an axe, womp womp.

If you want to play easy mode, don't play this game.
You have to build and maintain your car as every part has wear mechanics.

Not worth the time and effort due to bugs, glitches and the rubbish physics engine.
However if you use mods from the Nexus, this is playable.

Mods I have used:

Item rotation
Chase Camera - External View
MSC Editor
God Mode - for fun.
Paint anything mod - Can paint the engine.
Mini Map - Can help when getting lost.
Mosquito kill - Stop that annoying sound
MSC Duper mod - Duplicate items, when you need more than one.
Odometer fix
Panier 250 - Peugeot 205 Mod
Push Start - When the battery is dead
Repair hammer - Fix panels
Show bolt size - Tired of guessing sizes?
Custom number plates.
Better cheat box for fun, and fixing bugs.
You get angry at first but when you get some more cash you can really enjoy the game
I like it, I recommend if you have patience :D

Day 1 of losing my mind:
Tutorial is borderline non-existent, I like how the game doesn't hold my hand while building a car but how tf am I supposed to know that this dude has a cottage on an island with a fish trap on the porch???? Impossible to navigate in the game without googling the english translation of the map, never know what the time is, some dude calls me to pick him up from the pub I drive there to the other side of the map took like 15-20 minutes irl and he's not there. The camshaft that was bolted in, had a timing belt on and the timing cover on top of that somehow shot itself through the timing cover when I placed the engine on the workbench now I can disassemble the whole front end bc the camshaft is apparently a ghost that it can move through solid objects. I was riding the moped straight on a straight road and it decided to make a 90 turn at max speed multiple times, "pls be gud dis a early access gaem" my ass, it was released in 2016, waste of money, should have bought mechanic simulator.

Day 2 of losing my mind: 
So I really want to build that car, decided to give the game one more chance. Went to the store to buy cigarettes and alternator belt, also bought food, beer, oil and some other stuff. For some reason the game gave me only one shopping bag so I had to carry most things individually to the boat, took like 8 trips between the boat and the store and then 8 trips between the boat and the house kms. Had to reload the save multiple times bc things kept on messing up, but the game doesn't save state of things like the engine hoist or the car jack so if you have your car jacked up and the hoist lowered and you save your game be ready to do that again bc they'll go to their default position. Took me an hour to figure out how to put the engine on the hoist at least I knew I wasn't alone reading the comments on reddit and everybody raging. Ran out of fuel in the middle of the lake, turns out you can't just pour in oil and then gas into the two stroke boat engine, you have to buy the two stroke fuel. Took a bus but while the bus was still at the bus stop cars kept on crashing into the bus bc the drivers are blind and can't slow down so the bus had like 6 cars piled up behind it, the bus driver got up and fking left and got stuck in the ditch by the road walking on the spot. The phone keeps on ringing fk off grandma I'm googling how to take the helmet off. I spent more time googling and watching youtube tutorials than playing. No tutorials for the engine building that's easy, but tutorials for random bs the game fails to explain like how to deal with stress, or what to do when you accidentally flip the car on its roof by brushing against its fender while working on it. Tried installing the dashboard and it kept fking falling apart, watched a tutorial on youtube just to confirm that yes I was doing everything correctly, works in the youtube video doesn't in game like wtf, then I tried to put in the dashboard one more time and this time not only did it fall apart but it also broke the fking windshield fk this game. I'm not a rage quitter, the last time I rage quit a game was probably like in 2013 playing cod, usually I make fun of rage quitters for taking games too seriously, I just wanted to relax building a car after work while I wait for parts for my real car. I rage quit two days in the row fk this game.

Day 3 of losing my mind:
Built the engine, wired everything, built the suspension, had a good time playing the game for the first time. Then I decided to head to the store for oil and gas so I can try to start the car up for the first time, crashed on the way and died. Turns out perma death is on by default so lost all the progress seriously fk this piece of sht game what rtrd came up with default permadeath ffs you gotta be kidding.

Finland Simulator 1995. You just enjoy the life in Finland. What else would you want.

+ Story
+ Map
+ Voice acting
+ Quality models
+ Perkele

- Nothing, this game is perfect. 

/jk

+ Open world
+ Lots of stuff to do, such as taking part-time jobs, shopping, visiting local concert, building and tuning dad's old car and racing with it or dating
+ Mini-games on a computer you can buy in-game
+ Lots of mods available

- The game is pretty difficult, so if you are a person who rages a lot, this game isn't for you.
- Not well optimized (but there are mods, that can improve the game's performance)

I spent 4 hours on this game and couldn't get it to work. 3 of those hours were spent looking at videos and reading guides online to see if I was doing something wrong but I couldn't figure out what was wrong. I really wanted to like this game and I gave it more chances than I should have but critical parts of the game just didn't work.

I'll recommend something if you actually want to enjoy this game and you aren't a masochist. Look up a guide and actually put the car together yourself, its worth doing at least once because its so rewarding, after that though, download a program called MSC editor and fix all the parts conditions because satsuma takes the word "unreliable" to a whole other level. You can try out some of the jobs if you want but I think you'll quickly find you'd rather just give yourself 99999 money because this game is hellbent on making your experience as miserable and stressful as possible. All that said... 10/10 I absolutely love it.

As a fellow Finn,
I get nostalgic about Finland in the late 1990s when I play this game.
This nostalgic car-building game is made even more unique by its simple but distinctive graphics.
The most accurate representation of the Finnish summer may be found in this game.

Put simply, it's the most irritating game ever, but it's also one of the most fun ones!

I freaking hate this game.  That being said I'm going to keep playing it because I like shitty car games that punish me.  I'll just tell you how it goes here:

The Good:
-Fairly realistic mechanic functions.
-It's hard in that weird sort of way that i like?
-It's a progressive car game
-You have a boat, mini-bike, and a tractor.
-Alcoholism galore.

The Bad:
-You get punished HARD for everything.  you have a drunk ass cousin that will ram right into you on the road, and if he dies? you got to jail for 5 days, which is 10 IRL hours.  Gotta hack your save file to delete it.
-Don't have transportation stored everywhere? get ready to die bitch.  you'll thirst to death before you get anywhere.
-Mechanics are wonky as fuck.  you can lean into your car to tighten a bolt and it can go flying into a wall leaving it unfunctional and needing thousands of dollars to fix.
-money's dumb.  you get a decent job every once in a while and everything takes forever.
-foods wild. your house is a good ways from the only store and it only restocks once a week, not a huge deal but at first it takes a long time to get there.
-mechanic shop can even mess up your car.  took my car there, running (albeit on choke) and asked him to tune it.  now it's sitting there, body panels multi colored and it doesnt run at all.

all in all, fuck this game.  that being said, i'll keep playing it.  when it's going good, it's fun.  but it'll fuck you in ways that make you think dark souls is fucking pokemon.

The game is amazing. I love the idea, I always hated the lack of realism in other car games. Your car would be pretty much invicible to things like bad shifting and the engine could only break in ONE way, first it smokes, then the smoke is darker, after that explosion/fire. That's it in every car game, except for My Summer Car. I'm just really annoyed that the rally is so hard, I think I'm just gonna give up on doing it. I'm really impresed that with all the parts installed, the fps for me is around 30, if you want more you can delete the "items.txt" file, buy the belt and battery. 
In conclusion this may be a very exhausting and difficult game, but it is greatly rewarding! It feels absolutely joyful driving in a car you build yourself.

A wonderful take on a charming life simulator that doesn't take itself too seriously, set in the summer of 1995 Finland.

Dropped into a reality that might resemble one of your own as a youngster (at least parts of it heavily reminded me of my own, growing up poor in a small village living off of farming, chasing many of the same hobbies).

Your main objective and source of entertainment (but absolutely not only), will be fixing your dads old junkyard car.  You do not have to be a gear head to find enjoyment in the rather cathartic process, it is much more of a hobby kit for a age 9+ kid, but dad better read the instructions to make sure everything works properly.

If you find zero value in the car process, you can take part of day to day life, helping your neighbours and family with odds and ends.

Charming at its core, and that is such a hard aspect to capture for most games that end up feeling soulless.

There are so many unnecessarily frustrating bugs with the game, like physics making your car do circles in your garage after you properly jack up the vehicle to remove the tire, essentially ruining your mortal life save game after 20 hours (playing it vanilla, not using 3rd party save editors to fix the game ruining bugs).

There is so much potential for masterclass level of playable art in a video game form, here.

This game will consume DAYS of your life. You will never run out of things to repair, replace, upgrade or tune on your car, you will never run out of quests to complete or groceries to buy or places to explore. This is one of those games where you have to read the wiki to understand its mechanics and make progress but it's fun nonetheless since it's very rewarding to finally hear your car idle, or installing a new part and breaking your previous speed record. The mechanics of this game are complex, not just the things you do with your car but just about every other action you do in the game such as brewing homemade alcohol, pumping septic tanks, grilling sausages or delivering fire wood. Npcs have surprisingly complex behaviour, voicelines and the game world offers a great level of detail and immersion despite the low level graphics which (to me at least) has a certain charme. Driving physics and having to acitvely shift your car or truck is super fun. But to use a gamepad effectively, you have to use Joy2Key to map your right analog stick to mouse movements to move the player camera which is a big deficit, however there are tutorials to setup joy2k. Also, playing without MSCEditor (to edit save files) is a pain but i dont have to use it very often.

ALSO, this game is fucking hilarious: Brutal car crashes with your drunk cousin, pissing on people, drunk driving and flipping of  cops, boxing drivers, dumping a literal load of shit onto someone's property... the list goes on.

The best computer game ever made in Finland, period. The game can also manifest infinite frustration in the player. Like the last time I played, I had built the car, gotten it inspected, had a nice sum of cash at hand, was getting ready for the rally. Then one weekend I decide it's time to win the fight at the dance pavilion. So I drink up, take the moped to the dance, win the fight, get the watch and then hitch a ride home with the red car. Big mistake. At the very last corner before home, the car smashes into a tree. KIA, thank you for playing. 10/10 would play with permadeath again. There are so many ridiculous ways to die in this game, I probably haven't even experienced them all. I hear you better not piss on the TV. 

Also, if you want to learn about cars, the mechanical side of the Satsuma is pretty realistic. Even though it cuts some corners, the basics are all there. 

Best of all, for someone who grew up in the 90's MSC truly feels quite nostalgic. Just put some 90's hits in to custom radio folder to complete the experience.

WARNING: This game is not for the faint hearted.

This game from the start, is designed to be difficult for new players. If i were you, i'd first watch somebody play this game, exactly how i managed to find this game. Do not go into permadeath mode for your first playthrough. I have died about six times trying to rally in permadeath. only to literally be met with a second place finish. If you find this game boring after while, like right after you're done building your car, i suggest tinkering with mods. A must have, no matter what kind of player you are is MOP. It optimizes the game, although at a risk because it is not being supported anymore. Once you have finished building the car multiple times, you can start to shave off and cut time to become faster at building, this is when, if you want to be a permadeath player. Do remember that this is a game, and only curse out the game when something physics breaking does happen. 

Like my first review, you can roll over 5 times doing highway speeds, but hit a tree at almost a crawl can kill you.
Good luck to anybody with a deathwish on permadeath, or playing this game in general.

This game I would say is one of my favorite games out there, this game is grindy and boring, and you will easily get you pissed off. You have to build a car from scratch. Do jobs around your town to get money to build your car. If you crash your car you have to rebuild the damn thing. But there is this freedom in this game that I don't see to often in other games. You can customize this car however you want. Put a turbo and nitro in the car and get drunk and crash into oncoming traffic. You can do whatever you want. And once you have finished making this car you race it in a rally and try to win first place. Grind achievements at the end. have fun(:

NOTE:i love this game, anyone who knows how numbers works can tell that, but i simply cannot recommend it as of 2023. 

for starters, back in late 2016-early 2017 when all the updates were big new features or fixes to massive issues and the core content of the game remained untouched it was great, you had a van and truck from the start, the wheels were in the garage, and the oil filter, battery, and spark plugs weren't replaceable items (although i don't mind the fact that they are now).

However, this game has slowly suffered from the dev wanting to make it seem like progress is being made and it's just on a back burner compared to my winter car but it's been done in a way that, in my opinion, sacrifices some of the enjoyment. the van and truck are no longer in your hands the moment you hit new game, instead you have to install certain parts on the car, then wait a random period of time, then sleep and check your uncle's house every morning for the van. if you find it there, great! ask your uncle for the keys (knock on his door) and drive off, but he takes the keys back after a while and you'll have to ask again so you're completely out of luck if you cant drive the satsuma for whatever reason. sure the tractor and Jonnez (and the boat but i havent touched it in years due to this games janky physics) exist but none compare to the van.

As for the truck it's a similar situation, after enough time of you using the van has passed your uncle will lose his licence for drunk driving and for whatever reason decide to hand the keys to his truck over to you, the truck is now parked in the town's sewage treatment plant, so good luck getting there if you cant use the Jonnez (or boat).

Next is the situation with the satsuma itself, firstly was wiring, which many found annoying but it's relatively simple (just remove the headlights and one of the starter bolts and then spam f randomly until the car starts again) then they added consumable batteries, spark plugs and oil filters, which again wasn't too big of an issue in my eyes as you need to get to the shop (problems with that somewhat discussed above) anyway.

The true issues come with what extra content HAS been added relatively recently, mainly the new jobs, haybale and strawberries, the haybale job is a one-off you do for a farmer who cant work himself, but the haybales are scattered about the map and the only vehicle you can move them with is the tractor, making it incredibly tedious. the strawberries job is simple, go to the strawberry farm and harvest the strawberries, but (i've been trying to avoid swearing this whole review but since it's an 18 rated game anyway and im making a point) you get FUCK ALL in terms of pay for doing it, and it takes ages so it's completely pointless effort that could've been spent developing parts of the game that are more important.

something that was added that many do find useful was the Ruscko, another means of getting yourself from point A to B, you can steal it off this weird pig-guy (not making that up) or gamble your car (yes, the satsuma, the entire reason you'd play this game) away in hopes of winning his instead (shit deal) however it has a wasps nest in it, the simplest solution to that is wait until after 8pm (when it's dark basically) and use the tractor to drown the wasps (will take a while to get there) or use the fire extinguisher on them (can be done with Jonnez and is faster but costs money) and your reward for this? the worst car in the game. the Ruscko:
1: cannot start properly
2: has broken electrics
3: wiper switch is broken
4: dead wasps nest permanently there
5: horrible fuel economy
6: looks ugly as hell (but to be fair that was the whole idea for the car)
7: has next to no fuel in it when you first get it
8: if you steal it, the horn blares when you go over bumps (lmao)
9: cannot be repaired (without mods)
10: isn't road legal, and the police can catch you driving it on the highway
so while it may be better than the tractor for those first few shop runs while you're getting started, beyond that it will end up sitting in your driveway rusting away, screwdriver in the ignition (unless you seriously gambled the satsuma for it)

But yes, definitely recommended.

I love the game, I bought it, and use a mod, that allows me to get infinite $, teleport, turn off needs, and yea, I just like the game for the building aspect! So thats all this review will be based on.

Building The Engine:
      Building the engine had to be the BEST experience in the game for me. Just the feeling of finally getting it running is amazing. There is a limited number of upgrades, BUT, you need to work hard to get them, tuning also adds more to it (mentioned later).

Breakage Of Parts:
      I love and hate this, the realism is great, but, also, wants to kill you (literally). I think it involves a interesting experience for working on and fixing cars. A weird part is, you break piston 1? Boom, Fleetari magically has it! Its neet that you can repair parts with the "Dingging Bar" that let's you "fix" (kinda) body panels, etc.

Tuning:
       Tuning provides a lot of preformace, especially further in the game. The littlest turn can change your engine completely. Or suspension! It's awesome!

Earning Money:
      You can do multiple things to earn money, for example, you can chop wood, do sewage stuff, delivery jobs, gambling, and more!

Buying Upgrades:
      You can spend your hard earned money on parts to win the local rally! That's literally it. Tbh it's a status thing lol.

Overall:
       My Summer Car is a life simualtor disguised as a car game, you are a guy in your 20s in the Finnish countryside, and you have to build your parents car while they are on vacation (they never return, it's not a story thing, it's just not a story game.) over the summer. While having to survive the harsh Finnish countryside.

I really can't see how this game has good reviews, as of right now It's absolutely horrible. Very confusing, poor ui, poor moving controls, etc. You can't assign mouse buttons, or keys to multiple functions even when they don't interact (ie, LShift to sprint cant be use to shift gears up in your car). Additionally, the driving mode function just locks your person in place, doesn't center you onto the seat or anything. Additionally, trying to get onto the motorbike (your only beginning vehicle that works) you just end up knocking it over because you have to literally jump on top of it for the driving mode prompt to pop up. Also, the controls to assemble are the same to drop an object, so when trying to assemble your car you just end up throwing the object half the time. Honestly, it just seems very unpolished for an early access game that's been our for over 7 years, to the point where it seems like it was only worked on for a year at most.

Rating: ★★★★☆

"My Summer Car" is a wildly unique and oddly charming simulation game that invites players to dive into the eccentric world of rural Finland, where you'll assemble a car, manage your daily life, and navigate the quirks of Finnish culture. Developed by Amistech Games, this game offers an unconventional yet surprisingly engaging experience that combines automotive mechanics, survival elements, and open-world exploration.

At its core, "My Summer Car" revolves around the simple premise of building and maintaining a car from scratch. You begin with a disassembled car and a cluttered garage, and it's up to you to piece it all together, bolt by bolt. The attention to detail in car assembly is nothing short of impressive, as you'll need to use tools, read manuals, and troubleshoot issues, creating a satisfying sense of accomplishment when your car finally roars to life.

Beyond the garage, the game immerses you in the daily life of a Finnish teenager during the 1990s. You'll need to manage your character's needs, including hunger, thirst, and hygiene, which adds an intriguing layer of survival gameplay. Venturing into the open-world environment, you'll encounter quirky characters, explore the scenic countryside, and engage in activities like fishing, drinking at the local pub, and even participating in the infamous rally races.

The game's realism extends to its driving mechanics, which accurately simulate the experience of operating a car. Navigating the challenging Finnish roads, especially while intoxicated, can be both hilarious and maddeningly frustrating, making for some memorable moments.

One of "My Summer Car's" unique features is its brutal difficulty and lack of handholding. The game doesn't hold back on its steep learning curve, and your character can meet a variety of untimely and gruesome ends if you're not careful. This unforgiving nature may turn off some players, but it also contributes to the game's quirky charm.

The open-ended nature of "My Summer Car" means there's no traditional storyline, and the game relies on player-driven experiences. This can be both a strength and a weakness, as some players may miss the guidance of a structured narrative.

In conclusion, "My Summer Car" is a game that defies easy categorization. It's part automotive simulator, part survival game, part open-world adventure, and all wrapped up in a charmingly eccentric Finnish package. The level of detail in car assembly and the immersive rural setting make it a standout title for those seeking a unique gaming experience. While its steep learning curve and lack of traditional storytelling may not be for everyone, those who embrace its quirks will find themselves immersed in a wonderfully odd and engaging virtual summer in Finland. Prepare for a summer you won't soon forget, filled with cars, saunas, and plenty of surprises.
