Rating: ★★★★★ (5/5)

My Summer Car is nothing short of a gaming masterpiece that offers an unparalleled and immersive automotive experience. Developed by Amistech Games, this quirky and meticulously crafted simulation game stands as a shining example of how gaming can transport players to a unique and captivating world of its own.

In-Depth Car Building:
My Summer Car's crowning achievement is its incredibly detailed car-building mechanic. From selecting and assembling each part to tuning and fine-tuning your vehicle, the game's attention to automotive realism is extraordinary. Building your car is a deeply satisfying journey that offers a sense of accomplishment like no other.

Realistic Survival Mechanics:
The integration of survival elements adds depth and authenticity to the game. Balancing hunger, thirst, fatigue, and personal hygiene while navigating the Finnish wilderness creates a genuinely immersive experience. It's a testament to the developer's commitment to realism.

Open-World Exploration:
The world of My Summer Car is vast, rich, and impeccably detailed. The Finnish countryside, complete with dense forests, serene lakes, and quaint villages, feels like a living, breathing environment. The freedom to explore this picturesque landscape is both liberating and awe-inspiring, fostering a true sense of adventure.

Complex Gameplay:
My Summer Car embraces complexity, offering a challenging and rewarding gaming experience. Its learning curve may be steep, but for those willing to invest the time, the sense of achievement is unmatched. The intricate gameplay mechanics make it a true standout among simulation games.

Quirky Sense of Humor:
The game's quirky and offbeat sense of humor is a delightful surprise. From the eccentric characters you encounter to the absurd situations you find yourself in, My Summer Car's humor adds layers of amusement and surprise, ensuring that every moment is filled with laughter.

Modding Community:
The passionate modding community surrounding My Summer Car enhances the experience even further. With a wealth of user-created content, enhancements, and quality-of-life improvements, the game remains fresh and exciting long after your first playthrough.

In conclusion, My Summer Car is a perfect gaming gem. Its unparalleled attention to detail, immersive world, and balanced complexity combine to create an experience that's both deeply satisfying and endlessly entertaining. Whether you're an automotive enthusiast, a simulation game lover, or simply seeking a unique gaming adventure, My Summer Car is a must-play. It's a testament to the boundless creativity of the gaming industry and a shining example of how a game can transport players to a world unlike any other. This game served me, a then-14-year-old car enthusiast, well for the handful of years leading up to the day I would become 17, at which point I'd finally be able to get a license and drive cars in real life.

As you can imagine, the 4-years of owning this game had taught me a lot. Prior to playing this game, I had a very limited understanding of the manual transmission from the few games I played that had them, such as Need For Speed Carbon on the Wii, and CSR Racing on the phone. Even then, those games didn't have clutches. But My Summer Car does! This game simulates all the components you'd be using in a late-'70s car.

I like the aesthetic of the game, while I was not alive in 1995, I do think it succeeds in portraying the look and feel of that year. (It is a lot more believable than Yandere Simulator's "1989", might I add.)
I also like the controls of the game, it works well even with a keyboard, although I wouldn't recommend doing the rally with it, as you'd lack the analogue brakes needed to not under-steer into a tree at 120 km/h.

I really like how hard this game is. If you thought Street Legal Racing: Redline was punishing. This is a whole other level... If you crash, you have to painstakingly tighten each bolt after putting the parts back on, and that's the best outcome you're gonna get for a crash. Usually, you'd die, and have to walk back to the wreckage to reassemble the car, in a ditch. Even after that, you're not out of the woods yet; the fuel has all leaked out, the windshield has come out, you've got to limp to the fuel station with the last fluid ounces of fuel left in the tank to buy more fuel, and a new windshield. To get the money for that stuff, you work. Namely, manual labour.

As for what I don't like... I don't like how hard this game is to run smoothly. It isn't the best optimised game out there, nor is it the least buggy, for that matter. (Don't tighten either of the Disc Brake Rotors' 14mm bolts until you have installed the halfshafts, otherwise your car won't put the power down.)
This last point is gonna sound like a nit-pick... The bolt sizes in the game are so impossibly small, notably the hood and bootlid's 6mm bolts.

In conclusion... If you've a car enthusiast, looking to go back to the '90s, and you've got a deeply beefy CPU, with heaps of RAM, you can't go wrong with My Summer Car.

My Summer Car is a wacky Finnish life sim, which tasks you with restoring your dad's old car. Or more accurately, rebuilding it from a pile of parts left in the garage. The engine needs a complete assembly, the suspension is in pieces and the interior and wiring are in a similar state. Perhaps there's a consumable part or two missing as well? And where are the tyres?

You will need to use other modes of transport available to go out and complete odd jobs around the local area to raise funds to repair your car and buy enough food to keep yourself alive. The jobs are quite varied, but might become repetitive after a long playthrough. To alleviate this, you can find some more interesting ways to make money one-off, which I'd recommend you hunt for as they can be quite fun.

The game does require a base level of mechanic knowledge, or the willingness to follow a guide (unless you want to spend hours figuring out how to build and engine on your own) so be warned going into this one that it doesn't hold your hand one bit. There are some simplifications of processes, but otherwise it's surprisingly authentic in terms of putting a car together from scratch.

Once you've got your car up and running, you may want to make some less-than-respectable modifications to it to get it ready for rally or drag racing, or you might just want to get it in good condition and take it out on regular drives. It's up to you how you play this game. Aside from making sure your needs are met, there is a lot of freedom in how you play this game.

An easy game to recommend, so long as you're aware it's very slow going and can be frustrating due to the numerous ways you can die (and potentially lose your save if you play on permadeath!)

My Summer Car is a brutal, unforgiving life simulator that wants you to do something most players have no chance on earth doing without help.

I'm not one for difficult games and I couldn't care much about cars either, but for some reason this game speaks to me. Maybe it's the nostalgic country dirt roads or the immersive rpg interactions that fill this game like grandma offering less money if you have prison tattoos or npcs stealing and wrecking your stuff if you mess up their day.

It's far from a cinematic gameplay experience. There is no background music and you spend a lot of time driving down the same lengthy routes to carry out chores and shopping runs. This is just a simulation of living as a guy in a low-income, outdated settlement who's in need of some street cred.

Worst game I ever bought, including that one I bought that wouldn't run at all and just crashed on loading - this game is worse than that.  
1)  If you play on a keyboard - keyboard keys are either pressed or they are not pressed - there is no way to activate a key 'a little bit' or 'half way' - therefore there is not a good way to simulate the use of a vehicle's clutch on a keyboard.  Sure you can rev the engine to max and pop that clutch and just hope for the best, and sometimes it will even work, but is this really a good thing to have in a game?  Not for me.  
When I saw that the dev had done this, it brought up so many questions for me, like:  When I build a car later , will I be expected to link the steering wheel to the carburetor or will it have a normal steering components?  Am I going to be required to do some other impossible-to-accomplish-on-a-keyboard task that I cannot find a way to sometimes work around?  This is a game about building a car and driving.  American Truck Sim, Farming Sim, most every other game dev gets that you can't expect folks to operate a clutch normally with a keyboard.  If I'm missing something here, please point it out.  I am having a hard time believing that this is an actual game mechanic; start the vehicle, stall it, start it, stall it, start it stall it, and at some point, maybe if you are on a hill, you'll get rolling.  
2)  For me personally, a valid game challenge is something like:  How do I get more money?  How will I assemble this machine?  How do I obtain a resource with which to finish this task?  These are the challenges I expect.  The challenges in this game are of a different type.  They are like:  which mystical combination of buttons is going to allow me to close this door?  Which, seemingly arbitrary, combination of buttons would allow me to dip water out of a bucket with a ladle?  Why does the motorcycle make a crashing noise every time I figure out the mysterious series of buttons that would allow me to sit on it?  I know how to close doors, dip water out of a bucket, and sit down in real life, so a simulation should not make these into major obstacles to overcome.  For me, this makes it no longer a simulation, but a puzzle of the type that does not appeal to me.  (After 40 minutes and a tutorial, I still could not dip water out of that bucket.)     
These type of obstacles ruin the immersive quality of a game because they force one to focus on the keyboard and not the game.  I look at this type of thing as a very cheap way to challenge players.  It requires no creativity, no thought - and it inspires no further interest from the player.    
I'll save you the cost of this game - just do this:  I'm thinking of a random combination of buttons on a keyboard and mouse - can you guess what they are?  It's like code breaking, but I'm not telling you how many characters are in this code.  I'll give you some clues in the form of noises that won't make any sense within the context of your task.  If you guess right, you'll only accomplish something small, like closing a door, so there is virtually no reward for getting it right.    
That is what this game experience was like for me - even after mapping custom controls, even after watching youtube vids, even after reading info here and on reddit.  It was a good idea in theory, but so poorly executed as to be unplayable for me.  
Only recommended to my worst and most hated enemies.

It's quite fun, very realistic. $30 game quality, $15 game price. 11/10.
(EDIT) When I first wrote this review, I had about 8 hours on the game. Now that I have 100 hours on it, I truly know this game. I cannot recommend this game enough. You build and maintain your own car, get to interact with finnish culture in the mid-1990s, fall into sewage wells and take a drunk guy home from the pub. The possibilities are endless. Never before have I played a game where I took a break from rebuilding the engine out of my car to trickshot piss across the kitchen into the sink while drinking my own homemade sugar wine. Or taken a break from trying to learn a virtual computer OS to drink booze and accidentally hit myself with a hatchet while drunk. This game is truly a work of art, and ToplessGun deserves every cent of that $15 purchase price. I cannot wait for My Winter Car to release. 100/10.

After 14.5 hours on the clock, it'd be far less stressful to immigrate to Finland, buy a house in Rural Finland, get all the parts for a Satsuma car and actually build a Satsuma than it is to play this game.  I really wanted to like the game, but this is more tempermental than building an actual car in real life.

I've played for 14.5 hours, I've died 10 times (mostly due to physics glitches) and I've had to restart the game three times due to various issues.   I finally got to the point where the car had tires, the engine was assembled, but the final nightmare was trying to get the motor into the car and that was a whole fresh heck.   How in the seven worlds do you manage to get a car SIDEWAYS IN THE GARAGE?   I don't know, but that thing was in there sideways thanks to the glitchy as heck engine hoist.   It's like the game was intentionally made to be punishingly difficult.

I've built cars before, it's not easy.  But at least you don't have to worry about the engine clipping through the subframe, or suddenly deciding to launch itself through the firewall, or FLIP THE ENTIRE CAR OVER!  I just gave up at that point. 

I tried to do the haybale task with the tractor to get more money and even that was complicated to all heck.  I used to spend my summers loading haybales for my uncle's ranch, it's not anywhere as difficult as the game makes it.  I had to resort to modding to be able to load the hay bales and then I couldn't find where to drop the bales off at because no map to reference!

I shouldn't have to resort to mods to make this game even vaguely playable.  I shouldn't have to constantly refer to google searches to figure out how to do various basic tasks.  This game was a promising premise, to build a car, but in the end it just ended up being torture.  I think I'd rather play in the road and wait for that guy in the green car come by and mow me down than continue playing this game.

This game is a driving god.  

This game is one of the hardest learning curves ever but really rewards you with each step of the way without meaning it.  Once you get the engine in the car body, you feel amazing... just to remember the fact you still have to do all the wiring.  The game is great if you love being pissed off at every last thing.

I really recommend if you love changes and learning curves, this game isnt for everyone but its for me, you and your next house over friend,

This game used to be awesome, it used to have lots of minor bugs that almost helped you enjoy the game, it used to let you take dumb risks and risk completely ruining perma death saves for time save or trying quirky stuff that very well could break the physics engine (such as carrying the pit bike across the water on the boat). Recent development has taken a turn towards the worst solution. This game is just not fun anymore, all the fun ways to play have been patched out, but all of the major frustrating bugs like parts falling through the world or falling off the car between saves still exist. Every aspect of this game has gone from good to poor, it has plenty of detail, and posed a nice challenge. But I finally am uninstalling this game and won't be buying the sequel because everything I loved about MSC got ruined by a developer with a different vision for a game based on F***ing unity engine. I'm sorry.

TL:DR Developer has decided enjoyment should be traded for "patience" (just go live real life or play any other game). I used to enjoy this game with and without mods, but the developer has tanked it's playablity and ruined the prospects for the future of the series.

This might personally be my most favourite game of all time.

I cant think of anything similar to it and if you had to tell a younger version of myself that I would plunge 350+ hours into this I wouldn't know what to say. 

It has a sense of humour, the world feels alive despite the low graphical fidelity, the game design is intuitive and only struggles here and there with the fact that it is a life sim in a countryside setting in the 90s.

Buy this game if you are interested in how cars work, if you appreciate a tight but real world and if you are a bit abnormal.

30 Step MSC checklist.

1. Wake up.
2. Start building the car.
3. Ran out of food.
4. Go to store with tractor.
5. Buy food with (almost) 3000 marks.
6. Go back to house to finish the car.
7. Finish the car.
8. Realize most of the parts are useless and need to buy new ones from Teimo's.
9. Go back to store thinking they cost 50 marks.
10. Realize that it cost hundreds of marks.
11. Start doing jobs.
12. Get obsessed with doing random jobs, and forget why you started in first place.
13. After couple of hours (IRL) you go back to Teimo's to buy the parts.
14. Finish the car and start it.
15. Celebrate by drinking.
16. Buy better parts from "Amis-Auto Ky" and make your Satsuma better.
17. Join the rally.
18. Lose the Rally.
19. Wait a week (In-game) time and try again.
20. Win the rally.
21. Celebrate by drinking.
22. Bully the local "Amis" called Jani.
23. Make him crash.
24. Kidnap his girlfriend.
25. Bring back home and help her.
26. Let her go and go to dates.
27. Take her to date.
28. Drink until you blackout.
29. Get girl pregnant.
30. Nine mounts later drive to hospital while your girl is giving birth to your son.

This game is the perfect representation of a love-hate relationship. You feel good about your skills in motor building and get started, you finish it and plop it in the car. You go buy parts for your project and find wheels in an abandoned shed somewhere. Bolt everything down one by one, it is finally complete. 

It doesn't start because you have dead battery. 

You go to store to buy new battery and are horrifically killed in a motorbike accident.

Quit game for a while, browse your Steam library and decide it's time to torture yourself once more and do it all over again, enjoying every second.

Suomi perkele vittu simulation nine million is hard, and unforgiving. There is a certain Scandinavian harsh fairness to the game; if you chop wood while drunk, you cut your leg off and die, if you sling your shitbox Satsuma around a corner into a tree, you die, if you break down in rural Finland far from home with no beer, you die.

But when your peice of shit Japanese car finally, finally moves under its own power, after three days of drinking beer, swearing, missing bolts, and physics related incidents, you feel like the king of the world. I give it a score of 10 tedious Finnish summer days out of 10.

This game is like non-vr surgeon simulator, where the unrealistic difficulty of mundane tasks is a large part of the game. You'll only like this game if you've somehow managed to convince yourself that tedious, difficult gameplay IS what makes a game fun.
For everyone else, this game offers nothing but a time sink for those who like throwing away hours of progress to something out of your control.
It's okay to just stare the sweaty tryhards right in the face and tell them "It's not fun, and it's not worth my time, I'm not going to continue playing this game due to some feeling that I have to 'complete' it to feel satisfied." And then walk away, hopefully just within the deadline for getting a refund.

As I'm writting this review I have some mixed feelings for this game, I love this game, but i hate it as much as I love it and I'm sure that I'm not the only one who feels like this towards this game. This "life simulator" is one of the most "fun" games out there, but also one of the hardest ones out there ( That's what She said!!). Like, one minute everything is fine, you driving on a road with 90ish Km/h wich has the speed limit 60Km/h with a vehicle with a speed limit of 80Km/h, everything is fine until one noticeses that if you perform the "gutter run" you  can take a corner at higher speed, and next thing you know; you are on your "one-way trip" to heaven (or hell, depending) with the fist stop being a tree. Before you can press ALT-F4 you see blod al over the screen and Routainen maa playing.

Just for context, I am not talking of personal experience (JK I am, and i hate this game with every quark of my body, but i also love this game because it's diffrent form other games, that give you everything from the start , and always droping tips and hints, and we don't want to forget about the "ruberband effect" in other games. Cuz this game dosn't Help you in any way. It just want's to punish you for EVERYTHING that you could and will do.)

In short: This game deservs some hours of your life if you like automobiles and engines, you either Love or hate it, OR even both at the same time, it's at least like that for me.

This game is.. Alright. It isn't the smoothest, and it isn't the most engaging if you want to 100% it. But if you play long enough, it might just be acceptably fun. There are of course problems, like the final thing you can gamble at the Ventti hut being a crappy 50s station wagon with a wasp nest inside of it.. Speaking of wasps, wasps follow you forever after you make them angry, which it pretty infuriating. There is also a pretty annoying bug which, if you press ESC twice, the pause menu will be permanently displayed on your screen without you being able to interact with it. The only way to remove the menu would be by painstakingly making your way to a toilet and exit with saving, or to manually close the game from steam. But all of those issues aside, this game is pretty good! I honestly can't wait to see what it will look like when it's finished.. Maybe these bugs will be fixed by then? :)
Never thought I would play this game, but here we are. Work hard, play even harder. Be smart and mange your progression and saves. This is not a game to be taken too seriously, just have fun with it.

A f*****g masterpiece. Responsible for spawning the life sim/car building genre. Requires some basic knowledge of cars and engines. The world is an interesting place packed with secrets and hidden things to discover. NPCs abound and some are friendly and others complete jerks. The game is much more then building a car, its discovering the bygone small Finnish village life of the late 20th century.

I have played the game for 15 hours and I could not recommend this game for the reasons below.

1. The game is out to punish you from the start
2. The jobs are tedious and repetitive
3. The food spoils to fast and keeps you from focusing on building the car
4. The physics are bad
5. Some AI buses/cars go around you and some just crash into you just to punish you

The only reason I like the game is to build the car and customize it but the dev/s has taken the fun out of that with constantly forcing you to do repetitive tasks. I will not be purchasing my winter car if it come out unless it changes and allow you time to enjoy your car building without all the non-sense.

With all that said, the game is funny and you can use mods to make the punishing stop.

Edit: After learning more about the game, I am changing my view on it and do recommend the game. I suggest to watch some videos on the game before trying to play it as their is no manual for the game to get more familiar with the game.

Very fun, rewarding and immersive game. The building of the car and engine maintenance is all top-notch and the most unique aspect of the game, although unless you already know exactly how old cars work you will need to follow a third party guide. In fact, the game has no tutorial whatsoever; it is a hardcore life sim so buyer beware: you will probably spend a lot of time on the wiki (PS most things are intuitive but some game mechanics are not).

A lot of people complain that the game is too punishing, and while I agree it can be unfair when the police jail you when a drunk driver crashes into you and kills himself, the game forces you to be careful on the roads, follow traffic laws, plan for food and tanking up fuel just like you would in real life.

To conclude, I definitely recommend the game if this genre interests you, but if you are easily frustrated I would also recommend downloading some mods to make the most frustrating areas of the game easier.

Something I haven't seen mentioned are the piss mechanics. Probably the most realistic piss mechanic I've ever used in a video game. You press "P" to pee, which is easy enough. Once your piss bar hits a certain point, you have to start holding in the "P" button to get a little bit more out. Once it gets low enough, there's no pushing you can do and just shake the rest off. This is a flawless implementation of a man peeing, and for that I give the game a 10/10.

This is a fun concept, but horrible execution. The game is designed to waste your time in the most annoying way possible. It is bad on purpose. Not funny, or quirky. Just bad. Offensively bad.

Other games have uppdates that improves quality of life. This game has updates that decreases quality of life. By design.

It has the physics of Goat Simulator, the boringness of Euro Truck Simulator, the annoyingness of Getting Over It, the dull mechanics of House Flipper, the controls of QWOP, and requires the time investment of a major AAA role playing game, and the graphics are super ugly.

There is no core gameplay whatsoever. The whole game is just a bunch of accidents and circumstances. It literally takes hours to learn how to even use basic objects and drink water. Then your house burns down and you start over.

Actually building the car - you know, the main point of the game - is super boring and stupid. Again you are just spending your time trying to use the worst controls ever to find some super secret screw hidden in a super awkward angle.

There is no progression, no improvement. You can't learn new skills, and build your character. You are just stuck playing the village idiot, in the slowest moving place on earth.

No sane person with a life would ever play this game. Why on earth did they make this game?

A game where you can do anything except have fun. You wake up in a rural Finnish town with a pile of car parts and a thirst for adventure. You can drive, drink, assemble your car, eat, pee, and sleep. But unfortunately, this game has no guide, no goal, and no point. You will spend hours watching YouTube videos to figure out how to play this game. You will regret buying this game when you could have bought something more enjoyable like car mechanic simulator. This game is a waste of time and money. Don't buy it. (3/10)

My Summer Car is an absolute blast of a game that puts you in the driver's seat of an exciting and immersive summer adventure. With its unique blend of open-world exploration, car building and maintenance, and quirky Finnish humor, it delivers a truly unforgettable experience. From assembling your own car piece by piece to exploring the beautiful countryside, the game offers a wide range of activities that keep you engaged for hours on end. The attention to detail is remarkable, with realistic car mechanics and a living, breathing world to explore. Whether you're racing down the dirt roads, tinkering with your vehicle, or just enjoying a relaxing sauna session, My Summer Car captures the essence of a laid-back summer in the Finnish countryside. So grab your toolbox, jump behind the wheel, and get ready to embark on a hilarious and exhilarating journey that will leave you craving for more.

What starts as a meme game quickly turns into probably the most immersive sim you could play. 

The game manages to perfectly capture that 1995 feeling, for better and worse. All of the systems seem to contribute perfectly to the over all vibe, and you'll quickly find that the game isn't as difficult or as frustrating as the content creators would have you believe. 

The game's pretty fair all things considered, and any sort of "huh I wonder if this will kill me" is usually rewarded with death, but the "realism" is a 2 way street in this game, with plenty of shenanigans to offset the frustration of things like.. dying for not wearing a seatbelt.. or dying for getting stung by a bee. 

All in all, give the game a shot. Play it in standard mode if you want, or play it in permadeath. It's fun regardless.

Imagine spending days, even weeks, constructing your finest Lego creation. Your magnum opus of colorful plastic blocks. After enduring frustration, confusion, and general pain you find yourself feeling the bliss of true achievement. You've done it, the masterpiece is finished. You then immediately trip and smash it to pieces. Time to start from square one! Playing this game on permadeath mode is basically the same experience...

Don't get me wrong, this is a positive review. That's the point of this game. you're supposed to suffer the cruelties of life's unfairness. It may not be for everyone, but it certainly achieves what it aims to.

Hi I've had this game for a long while now and I will go ahead and review it now.

Here's a heads up this game can be funny and goofy, doesn't matter if its due to a bug or a feature this game can be super funny. But on the other hand it can get very dark (both in tone and lighting) If you are not in a clear head space I would say avoid taking the drunk guy home until you have a clear head space (this is due to how his story ends and it takes some time to do as well). Also this game is really hard even more so when you are new to the game so don't play on perma death. Also don't worry if you don't understand things (the game does a poor job of explaining some things like how to get the blue van or even wheels) that's normal and I was the same way starting off just pull up a guide when you think you need it. That said over time as you learn the game it does get easier I myself rarely die or have issues driving, It just takes time and practice to get a handle of the game.

It has a lot of potential, but it is extremely difficult without any outside help at all. The game doesn't give you any help for your first car build, making it the most frustrating thing ever. After seeing the fan base simply fawn over it, I can't understand why because it gives you all of the parts but none of the knowledge. You are basically sitting there fumbling in the dark because it somehow gives you too much but also too little. Not to mention, simply surviving makes it even more difficult because you have to take your focus away from the build. It could be great, but the lack of accessibility for newcomers is too big to ignore and thus made me hate playing it. An optional tutorial in game would fix this, or even better, a manual for the build. I should not have to rapidly search all over the internet for guides after only playing for 2 minutes. I really tried to like it, as seen by my 33 hour playtime, but I simply cannot play it without wanting to throw my desk out the window. If you are looking for a semi-relaxing and pleasant experience, you will be very disappointed, and more likely to be frustrated out of your mind. Not to mention that while it is an open-world game, there is no 'design' at all. You are basically meant to stumble upon things at random from what I can tell. It doesn't work, especially when your uncle's house is right behind yours, but it's hidden behind trees and hedges. You most likely wouldn't know its there unless you randomly walk out that way, which is how I found it. You also have to find wheels for the car, and the game tells you absolutely nothing. They are just in some abandoned mansion on the other side of the map. Literally everything in the game I either stumbled upon or had to look up in guides. It makes progress incredibly slow and annoying because you have no idea where to look for anything. Last, but not least, death. I don't mind the death mechanic, but the fact that if you don't have permadeath on, you respawn at a church ACROSS THE MAP from your house. Chances are, you will die trying to get back without having a vehicle there or something. Why don't you spawn back at home? That would save a lot of headache. And that's what I would call this game, a massive headache. It could be incredible, but the bad design and annoying decisions the devs made had created an unpleasant experience.

There are many words to describe this game: frustrating, slow, ridiculous, and tedious. But this game always has me coming back to it. It can be somewhat of a rage game at times, but there's something fun and charming about this game. If you're expecting awards for doing things, this game isn't for you. The only awards are the achievements and your own feeling of accomplishment. Knowing that you worked hard on something can be very rewarding. And you will have to work hard. Very hard. This game removes most remnants of sanity.

On top of that, you can't pause the game and places you can save at are scarce. You need to have a large time frame in which you can play this game. You can't just have 15 minutes to do something, because you won't be able to do much in 15 minutes. And even if you do, it's unlikely that you will be able to save your work. 

MSC Editor is also EXTREMELY necessary. It is a free program that allows you to edit your world. You WILL flip your Gifu at one point and you WILL NOT be able to flip it back up on its wheels. MSC Editor saves what little sanity you have left after playing this game.

It may seem like I'm just ranting about this game, but I do legitimately enjoy it. It has some more frustrating aspects, but that's what makes this game what it is. You don't expect to play My Summer Car and have an easy time doing things.

Well, as of this review the game was released 7 years ago and it is STILL in early access. Many memes of this game have been made, many swearing the entire experience is hilarious janky fun, and just a revolutionary game. 

Me personally? I played it because of the memes, I played it because it was popular and I just.... didn't like the game. It is easy to end up in a dead man walking state so easily. What is dead man walking? It means YOU ARE IRREVOCABLY ****ED. I wouldn't mind that, expect it can happen easily to a player that is unaware of the consequences of what they're doing. 

I played the game when it came out, I played it years later and it is STILL a janky mess where I basically have to youtube how to do things and read guides nonstop. Making a trip to the store? That could take about 8 minutes real time and you better not get lost, and you better have enough gas, food, water, etc etc whatever because if you don't you will lose your boat, your car, and have to remember where it was last and if you wreck your car, you gotta fix it. 

Ok, not a problem, I have 100's of hours in car mechanic simulator. I love car building games. This one though is PURE torture. I have to follow a youtube video step by step and its just not fun. I built the car twice. First time I built it I got it running, felt happy, took it for a spin, crashed it within an hour or two and uninstalled the game. Came back years later, rebuilt the car, then saw that now I have to do wiring, and uninstalled the game. Knowing what piece to connect and the *VERY SPECIFIC* magic pixel to look for is a frustrating experience and detracts from the experience. 

I wanna be Finnish, I wanna build a car, I wanna pick up my boy and drink and drive but nothing is intuitive and the consequences are so severe. Some people will tout, "yeah but thats what makes it fun!". Is that so? 

No its not so.

A very family friendly "life sim" game about building a car from scratch, drinking booze and relaxing in a sauna after a hard day of swearing and potential life threatening situations. 

Cutting the B.S this is a very fun game if you have the patience to build a car as well as dealing with some of the jank that comes with it (the jank is pretty much seasoning to this fine finnish dish though). You can always watch tutorials or walkthroughs of building the car for a bit of an easier experience as the building CAN be a bit tedious switching between spanners to find the correct size for screws, finding the screws, and or knowing how to properly "tune" the vehicle to get it functional.

The premise of the game is building the car to participate in the Rally. Or you can make it a disco on wheels, or factory restore it. Up to you. There are tasks to make money. Game details on the store page goes over all you can do in the game.

Its a fun time for 15 dollars, and especially for 5-10 when on sale. Again. I only recommend if you have patience and can handle some jank physics cause if you bump into the Satsuma oddly, either you or the car will become superman. Also, save often ;)

This game definitely appeals to a particular niche. Even with perma-death turned off, it is a pretty punishing and tedious game which can put off a lot of players. If you are a fan of simulator games, this one will appeal as it does not pull punches like some of the more arcade-y games within this category such as Mon Bazou. Chopping firewood and sucking sh*t with the sewage truck are time consuming and every bolt will frustrate you as you look for the correct sized wrench. 
     With all of that said, eventually the physics of the world and your interactions within it will just start to click, and you will enter into a flow where you really do feel like a young Finnish hooligan in another era. This is where the game shines the most as there is a ton of content hidden behind the initial tedium of surviving and progressing in this world. It is a game for those who are patient and willing to laugh at their failures as they learn the rules of the game. That patience will be rewarded however, as the game oozes humour and satire while feeling like a genuine slice of life in a small rural community. There are numerous achievements to seek and stories to follow which will inevitably make you laugh and maybe even cry. 

10/10 ~ Truly the Dark Souls of Finland simulators.

This game eats your lunch. Then it makes a nice seven course dinner... and eats that, too. Yet you will keep coming back for more.

OK. So this game does a pretty good, but not great, job of simulating what you need in real life to troubleshoot a broken car, after you assemble it from... I dunno, 100 or so parts? Feels like it, at any rate. The only problem is that you don't get the real visceral feeling of what's really happening with the car as you wonder what's wrong, nor all the real tools and references. It could perhaps use a little more "gamification" to hint at things, but that would likely detract from the pure simulation of it.

For example: The car is assembled and the starter runs and the choke is being used, but the engine doesn't fire, and the dash eventually fails to light. Is the battery dead? The charger says it's not. Do I have a voltmeter to check where something is not connected? Nope. Do I have a (insert popular name here) reference of wiring diagrams? Nope. Do I see empty wire connections? Kinda.

I'm not really trying to pick on what's lacking or overbearing. I'm simply stating that this game is difficult and will eat your lunch. And yet you will likely come back for more, because it's still entertaining... and you want that d**n car to run so you can drive it into the f***g lake that occupies most of the map, which makes you run in a big arse circle for several kilometres any time you want to go somewhere. F**k the boat, but don't because it actually helps. F**k the Jonnes, but don't because... actually, yes, to heck with the mostly useless, but fun to drive, Jonnes. There's a van... sometimes.

And then you find that mods are available to make you foam a bit less at the mouth. But the game still eats your lunch, unless you insist on super cheating, but then that would just make it all completely pointless.

So you go back for more.

Oh, make sure to use at least a game controller for driving, because keyboard driving a Jonnes on bumpy-ass back roads for 15 minutes, just to get a pack of smokes, sucks donkey...
It's like Skyrim with cars

Postmortem edit: Since the game is now more or less complete, I would like to add onto this review. I still enjoy it, but there are some severe issues within the game and a hefty amount of "dev says no" syndrome. 

A lot of this game has changed over the years, and honestly, not much of it was for the better. This game has always been a challenge to some degree, but recent updates have turned these challenges into chores. There is a lot of this game that exits just to be a dick, not to offer a challenge. 

The blue van on loan from your uncle no longer spawns in front of your house. This means getting to the store just to buy food is now a chore. You either have to make hour long trips into town with your moped or take the boat and leap frog items back and forth because you still cant carry more than one item at a time. In order to get (temporary) access to the van, you have to talk to your uncle. Your uncle may not spawn for days or even weeks at a time. To even trigger his spawn timer, you have to attach certain parts to your car. That means if you arent in the know, you may be waiting around for him to spawn...and he just wont. Thats just bad game design. 

The Ruscko, an already terrible car, has a patch note called "made Ruscko worse." The car is now effectively useless. It cant be used for store runs because its both unregistered and adding any item to the car, excluding the player, causes it to stall constantly. Why? Why do this? This seems especially dickish because you have to bet your own car in a poker game to get it. Why would you risk the Satsuma? A fully buildable and tunable potential race car, against a car that cant even start if you place a grocery bag on the passenger seat. Oh, and as a act of pure malice, even if you win the car, theres a bees nest inside it and your character is deathly allergic to bees. So fuck you. Better bring a fire extinguisher. 

The Satsuma now has to be inspected more than once. Before, once you got the car inspected you were good to go. Now, every couple weeks, you have to take it to the shop. This doesnt sound so bad until you realize that most of the aftermarket or racing parts arent road legal. So every couple weeks you will have to tear down your car, put standard parts in it, inspect it, then tear it down again and rebuild it with race parts. Now, this is nonsensical because to take part in the rally...your car has to be road legal. But to be road legal, you have to remove all your rally parts. Thats just being a dick. 

The Satsuma's windshield is always filthy. Always. Even if you get the car to mint condition you will always have a filthy windshield. Apart from looking terrible against a fresh coat of paint, this also hinders your view. You used to be able to simply remove the windshield but a new death type was added where you can have a bee hit your eye while driving...killing you instantly. That is intentional and of the many reasons why Im starting to lean closer to a thumbs down. 

You can lose your house through no fault of the player. House fires can just happen now, sometimes without any input on the player. Every time you use something electrical, there is a chance to cause a house fire. Cooking sausage on the stove? House fire. Start up the sauna so you dont have a random heart attack from stress? House fire. Turn on the TV? House fire. Thunderstorm? House fire. Once you lose the house, which mathematically will happen eventually, you lose access to a TON of content and jobs. 

The Gifu had an update that made it harder to drive, as well as a visual change in which the truck looks worse. Why would you do that? 

Fuel oil was added but this is essentially useless. Its cheaper than diesel but the fine for using it is colossal and you risk outright losing access to 2 vehicles. You CAN put it in the tractor, but ONLY during one job. Speaking of...

A new job was added where you collect hay bales. This job can suck a cactus. Its extremely long, difficult and pays less than some other much easier ones. It can mercifully only be completed once. I dont understand this job. It is beyond not worth it, its almost comical how not worth it it is. 

While building the Satsuma you will quickly notice that parts that used to spawn in the garage, no longer do. You will have to make a trip to town, which Ive already explained has become a chore, to buy several parts. AND, for some reason...your tires have been hidden in a mansion filled with bees on the other side of the lake. Why are the Satsuma's tires in the random attic of a random house? Was the dev high when he made this change? Its completely nonsensical. 

A computer has been added and unless you are fluent in Finnish, you cannot use it. Nothing on the PC is translated. I honestly can't tell if this was a slapdash addition or just another middle finger toward the player. 

The game finally received an ending that sets up the next game that the dev says will have even less freedom and more restrictions. This, I cannot fathom.

There is potential, but it's not worth the time investment to enjoy.

Be prepared to read a lot of online help guides as there is zero in game tuition.

Below are things this game could add for me to consider recommending it (not all but some at least);

- More intuitive menu
- In game pause
- In game instructions
- Fast travel system (at bus stops perhaps)
- In game map or at least a compass (not just the poster)
- Inventory system
- Slower draining needs bars
- To be able to jog for more than 10 minutes without dying.
- An indicator to when a red bar is about to kill you
- One-click tighten\loosen nuts and bolts
- Gamepad support

NOTE: Game played in offline mode for a few hours yesterday and today, my Steam play count is wrong.

This game requires a specific type of player who has a lot of patience and commitment. Its not the most polished game ever made so if you expect AAA quality then this isn't the game for you. If you don't want to look at guides or tutorials then this is not the game for you. Things take a long time in this game and if you don't have the available time then this game may not be for you. Now with all that being said once you get started playing it's a fun, but a times stressful experience. You can fully immerse yourself in the world, or just mess around. If building a whole car from nothing seems daunting to you I wouldn't be worried as a few guides will get you sorted. I was worried this game would of been too annoying or difficult to play when I first got it, but I've got say I've really enjoyed it and would recommend it to anyone who is patient enough to play it.

Honestly it took me over 100 hours in game to build up the courage to write this review.

They weren't lying when they said this game wont hold your hand. Unless you are willing to succumb to the fact you will have to learn A LOT of $hit in order to gain stability in this universe, you will hate your life. The fandom wiki is your friend, it has a comprehensive build guide that WILL allow you to build your SATSUMA 100%. It also has the descriptions for how to get jobs and successfully complete which is very very important for maintaining and modifying your SATSUMA.      

HOWEVER

Not known to the player is you may spend 40+ hours (As I did because of work limitations and not wanting to rush and make mistakes) to fully build your little car to learn that every new game has randomized car part integrity. My first game ever was such a struggle to get the car to run, Eventually because of sheer frustration and not wanting to just simply quit playing, I opted to use the EXTREMELY convenient tool/mod MSCEDITOR. Turns out my 4 tires, water pump, starter and alternator were essentially TRASH.  (0-5% durability.)

PROS: 

-You get to enjoy Finnish lifestyle at its greatest
-Mad fun car tuning and building, no joke so addictive.
-Wacky sandbox/ life simulator that makes me laugh often.
-Driving 200MPH into a tree and dying instantly.
-Getting that damn car to run is truly org@smic 


CONS

-Inherently buggy at times. :(
-Mosquito sound will genuinely make you question your sanity.
-Lack of direction is harmful to new player in my opinion.
-Lacking proper optimization.

MODS

Getting outdated but still active MOD community. Use MSCloader and not MODLOADER PRO as the latter has depricated and is no lonfer supported. I waited to about 80 hours until I started modding and I have no regrets.

My Summer Car is an absolutely fantastic game that provides a truly unique gaming experience. This game is not only incredibly fun and addictive, but it also provides players with an amazing level of depth and complexity that is rarely seen in other games.

One of the things that I absolutely love about My Summer Car is the incredible attention to detail that has been put into every aspect of the game. From the car building and maintenance mechanics, to the various mini-games and activities that you can engage in, everything has been thoughtfully designed to ensure that players are fully immersed in the experience.

The graphics and sound design in My Summer Car are also absolutely stunning. The game's visuals are incredibly detailed and realistic, and the sound effects really help to bring the game world to life. Whether you're cruising down the highway in your car or tinkering around in your garage, the game's audiovisuals create a truly immersive experience.

Another thing that I really appreciate about My Summer Car is the game's sense of humor. The game is absolutely loaded with hilarious jokes and Easter eggs that will keep you entertained for hours on end. Whether you're playing alone or with friends, the game is sure to keep you laughing and smiling throughout.

Overall, I would highly recommend My Summer Car to anyone who is looking for a fun, engaging, and immersive gaming experience. The game's attention to detail, stunning visuals and sound design, and hilarious sense of humor make it an absolute must-play for anyone who loves video games. So what are you waiting for? Get behind the wheel and start your engines today!

After previously leaving this game a positive review, at this point I don't feel like I can do it anymore.
Over the years, the dev has added a lot of content, and as someone who got this game many years ago, I think it hasn't been an improvement like one would think.
The game was notorious for being a pain, however there is a difference between a game being challenging, and then just simply tormenting the player. I think a prime example of this is the jail mechanic. The maniac in the green Fiat slammed into you on the back roads and died? Too bad, you're going to jail, which can't be skipped and the sentence takes a few real life hours. Think you're smart and cheat your way out of jail? Too bad, if your sentence isn't finished, then the cops will be waiting for you everywhere and put you in the slammer again. 
Other than that, the player character just developing an allergy to wasp sting to stop the practice of removing the Satsuma windshield was a bitch move, as well as adding the moped helmet.
The addition of house fires also made the sauna pretty much obsolete, because why risk your house permanently burning down when you can smoke a cig instead? All of the cool things people did were in some way patched out, because the dev decided that no fun was allowed.
I understand wanting to like challenging games, and I liked the challenge of old MSC, but right now while the game is still challenging, all of the old fun seems to have been leeched out of the game.
I hope that My Winter Car will be a way for the dev to address some of this, and perhaps from the experience gained from this game he will make something truly to look forward to.

My Summer Car is hands down the best game I have ever played in my life! From the moment I started playing, I was transported to a beautiful Finnish summer, complete with stunning lakeside scenery, endless sunshine, and the sound of cicadas buzzing in the background.

But what really sets this game apart is the attention to detail. The gameplay is incredibly realistic, and every action you take feels like it has a real impact on the world around you. Whether you're fixing up your rusty old Datsun Cherry 100A, stocking up on groceries, or just hanging out in the sauna with a cold beer, every moment feels authentic and immersive.

The car repair mechanics in the game are particularly impressive. It's incredibly challenging to repair the car, but the feeling of satisfaction you get when you finally manage to do it is unmatched. You'll spend hours tinkering with the engine, fixing various parts, and replacing broken pieces, all the while feeling the frustration of not being able to get it quite right. But when you finally get the car running smoothly, it's a truly magical experience.

Of course, things don't always go smoothly in My Summer Car. There are plenty of moments of frustration and despair, like when two of your pistons blow holes in the engine block, forcing you to start from scratch. But even these setbacks are part of what makes the game so immersive and rewarding.

Overall, My Summer Car is a must-play game for anyone who loves immersive, realistic experiences. It's the perfect way to escape from the real world for a while and live out your dreams of becoming a typical Finnish person – beer in hand, in a sauna, fixing up your beloved car. Trust me, you won't regret giving this game a try!

This game is amazing. It's silly, unforgiving, and SO much fun to play. let's get into the basics.

When you are creating a new game, you fill out a driver's license where you can import your own mugshot by modifying the game files. There is a permadeath option, though this is not recommended for people who get frustrated quickly. After creating your save you are dropped in your house. You have a van, a sewage truck, a tractor, and the shell of a project car (your summer car). Past the driveway you have a garage, containing many of the components to build the car. You have to completely build your engine, from block to air filter, with no ingame guides to hold your hand through the process. Alright, back to the real important stuff. In the top left hand corner you have your needs. They are as follows: URINE, HUNGER, THIRST, FATIGUE, and DIRTINESS (Stress now, too). If you don't take care of these, you will die. To get food, you need to drive to a store, which is along a dangerous road where driving into a tree will kill you. You save the game by clicking on toilets. 

Dying in this game fucking sucks. You generally always spawn back at your house and the gmae saves a few seconds after you die in the game so you dont have much time to ALT+F4. Also, if you crashed in your satsuma you might just end up restarting because the car is GOING to be totaled. Also, the car you died in remains where you died so you have to go get it with the tractor or another vehicle. I one time had a loop of dying trying to retrieve my vehicles so i just restarted. Also, theres a permadeath mode in this game, and dying one time in that mode deletes your save!

After you are finished with your engine, you need to insert it into your car. Before you do this though, you need to install the suspension. I'm not going to go into that, but instead tell what you're supposed to do next. In order to make your car have the best performance possible, you need to tune the carburator to adjust your air/fuel ratio. This is not recommended until you get the air/fuel gauge in the magazine, as you can (sometimes) permanently fuck up your engine, where it will backfire and die as soon as you start it and blow up (literally) if you put too much pressure on the engine (i know from experience as all that is currently happening and am attempting to fix it.) 

After you've gotten your car ready to go, you aren't done. While you were busybodying on your car, a strange letter came in the mail. Opening it up and finding strange scrabblings on it that looked like someone sneezed onto the page, you notice a big bolded number preceded by a dollar sign: 3,500 MK . Shit, you've got to pay your bills! And even worse, you don't have the money to pay for it! What could the remedy be?

SUCK SHIT! no really, you are given a septic truck by somebody (idk man u got it when the game starts) and your main method of getting money in this game is to perform sewage jobs for people. There are other ways to get money, too, but shitsucking is definitely the premier way to rake in the eds.

But yes, once you have amassed a small fortune, you now have the available capital to upgrade your car. Pretty much every part of your car can be upgraded, and you generally need most of these upgrades if you want to succeed in the rally.

What was that? The rally, I said? Yes! The general point of this game is to win the rally race. It is really hard to do and that's why everyone strives to do it (200 hours + no rally win sadge), but it is generally considered the endgame final boss. Be sure to install your rollcage and enhanced bucket seats before you do it, because one wrong turn or drift and you'll find yourself headfirst in a tree. There IS a real ending to the game, but I'll let you find that for yourself :)

Anyway, I give this game a 9/10. It's genuinely one of the most fun games I've ever played, and I can't talk enough about how much I like it. You will definitely not regret this purchase, unless you arent a fan of silly games like this, in which case, at least try it.

P.S.: Don't leave your sauna on.

I tried to like this game and i should of liked this game, but the game clearly didnt like me.

I enjoy Car Mechanic Simulator, but after awhile, i wanted more than the mediocre racing and the same loop of restore and sell. I saw some vids on this game from a few Youtubers i follow and the game looked just like what i was looking for. I finally tried it and can confirm my suspicions of: "Its a lot more fun to watch than play". 

I didnt spend much time playing MSC but i also didnt want to. I played long enough to build the engine and realized i would be fighting the very stiff/un-intuitive  controls all game and couldn't do it. Dont get me wrong, in 2016, a game of this calibur by a married couple is outstanding. However, in 2023 it very much shows its age and limits. I respect this game for setting the genre but i wouldnt recommend it today since its "children" (Mon bazou, Junkyard tuck, ect) are more refined even though they are just learning to walk.

The game has no direction what so ever, so its alot of trial and error. This can build up the sense of accomplishment, but also spawn unholy frustrations. If i wanted that, i would just play Darksouls/Elden Ring. I read that the dev himself said this game wasnt made to be fun, and he's right, it really isnt (to play at least).

Qucik Pro and Cons:
P - Survival gameplay loop thats naturally addictive
p - Very detailed car mechanics (especially for the time)
P - Has mods on nexus
P - Though niche, it is the foundation of the genre

C - The sound quality is pretty awful. I thought someone was crashing miles away but it was just me bumping the parts on the table in front of me.
C - Very stiff controls that takes time to get used to (they can be remapped but the extra mouse buttons cant be mapped which was a big deal for me)
C - Absolutely no direction in any capacity
C - Physics can bug out usually in a devastating way.

I could of sat down and just powered through and learned to accept my purchase. But steam thankfully is generous with refunds and my time in Mon Bazou was much more pleasant. This game isnt even a Gig which i now can see why.

 Lastly, the dev is apparently working on "My Winter Car" so i would rather see what he has learned with his time spent on MSC and hope it is  all it could be and more.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

6 tablespoons unsalted butter

1/2 cup white sugar

1/2 cup brown sugar

1/4 cup water

1/4 teaspoon cinnamon

1 pinch salt

5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced

1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).

Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.

Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.

Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.

Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.

Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

Its a very good game but its hard to learn and i had a mental breakdown after 15 minutes. So to those who see this here is how to drive the tractor and motorbike. So for the tractor you need to first get in it by walking into it like how you walk through the doors of your house. Then you want to enter drive mode you can do this when it says to enter drive mode in the middle of your screen, then once you've done that look for the "hand throttle" lever and pull it back just a bit with left mouse. Then look for the "ignition switch" which should be right next to it and hold that down with left mouse and at the same time hold W or whatever your throttle hotkey is. Then the RPM meter should start moving then you can let go of W and left mouse and pull the hand throttle all the back the same way you did early. After look for the "parking brake" it should be to the left down next to the door then click it to put it in the off position, or when it lowers. After you turn off the brake press G to go into gear 1 then you will start moving because of the "hand throttle" which you can raise and lower with left and right mouse buttons till you find a good balance and once you start moving go in front of the trailer then press B twice to start backing up. You want to back into the trailer hitch. When you here a click press G twice to start moving forward again the you can press R to change your range to high to move faster now this mechanic only apples to the tractor and sewage truck. Then you can drive the tractor with a max of 3 gears plus neutral and reverse you have 5 gears its G to raise gear and B to lower on default. The only thing i personally recommend changing is the "rangefinder" to "keypad 9" instead of R in the controls but that's your choice. 

If you want to use the motorbike you must first turn the "fuel tap" to make it be vertical (Up or down is your choice, I recommend down for speed and up for dependency) Then you can hop on the bike and enter drive mode the same way you did the tractor then once you do that move around a bit on the seat till you can use the "kick starter" and "kickstand" without having to lean over. (Note you will have to repeatedly enter and exit drive mode to do this) Then you want to raise the kickstand and after press the "kick starter" till the engine starts working then you want to hold down W while pressing G if you don't your engine is going to shut off. Now you can drive the motorbike which has a max of 4 gears that progressively get better as you cycle through them, also warning i'm a skilled driver (somewhat) in this game and the motor bike has claimed my life 5 times. So be careful on turns, and that's the end of My Summer Car how to drive by Professional Dumbass

Top tier game. 10 out of 10 👍

"gud game"

There is a Finnish song - almost a national anthem - called "Olen suomalainen", which contains the lyrics:
"We follow twists and turns, only to find / That it wasn't worth it at all"

My Summer Car is kind of like this - both in a positive and negative way. It is a superb simulation of a tedious and misery-inducing experience where everything is always against you. It is designed to troll the player: you may or may not find this enjoyable. It has no respect for your time. It kind of is funny ... but also kind of dumb.

The general feeling I get from the game is a constant sense of 
"lol wouldn't it be funny if..."
Wouldn't it be funny if the shop was as far as possible from your house, literally on the other side of the map, so that it took 30 real-life minutes to drive there? Wouldn't it be funny if the janky physics engine meant vehicles got stuck in the ground mesh every few minutes? Wouldn't it be funny if the jobs you had to do to get money were really boring and tedious? Wouldn't it be funny if there wasn't an inventory and you had to carry every single object one at a time?

The thing is, it IS kind of funny, to a point. The parody of Finnish rural culture is spot-on and hilarious, right down to the strange ornament someone bought on a holiday in Spain which will live forever inexplicably in the living room. It's funny when you go out to buy some sausages but get knocked off the road because you forgot the rally was on today, or how the only drinks in the game are milk, beer, and water straight from the tap. 

Or when you get to the shop late, just before it closes, but you can't fit everything on your crappy moped, so you have to drive home in the dark, except every time you get on the moped the janky physics ejects all of the cargo, and it's pitch black, and the stuff you bought flew into the trees and is impossible to find, and suddenly it's ... not so funny.

Because there's the real world. We have to do menial stuff every day. We don't get much time to play games. And after a long day of the real world, a challenge can be enjoyable, but this is just ... frustrating.

I built most of the car properly - and I have to say, it is mostly great fun to put the car together and hear it start up for the first time. Still, I ended up using a save editor at points to tighten some bolts and fill up fluids because I couldn't bear the tedium of doing it the "proper" way. After tuning the car, I was all ready to go, except to find that the steering is totally off. It's another "lol wouldn't it be funny if the player had to scroll their mouse 120 times (!) to fix the steering rods". I was done.

The developer of this game has expressly stated that he didn't have the intention to make the game fun. Before you buy this game, keep that in mind. The developer does not want you to have fun playing this game. It is expressly designed to be as tedious an experience as possible. It is designed to waste your time and infuriate you, and it's because the developer is an """"artist""""  who likes to frustrate people in a similar vein to all the dumpster grool that Bennett Foddy squeezes out, like Getting Over It and QWOP: Bad games that try to play off their shitty design as "quirky personality" or "artistic messages". The developer has gone on record expressly saying that he does not want the game to be fun, so here's my warning to you, in bold;

[b]The developer of this game has gone on record expressly stating that he does not want the game to be fun. It is not fun. Do not buy this game.[/b]

The main problems with this game is that it is both tedious, and unfair; and not the kind that might make the game challenging in a traditional sense, but the kind which should have it removed from the Steam Store, because the game borderline does not function in a playable state. 

For example, this game doesn't save when you sleep, only when you go in the game world to a toilet, which are few and far between in the game world. It can sometimes take upwards of 20 minutes to get to one, so if you have to step away from the computer suddenly, your progress is GONE. You can play for 6 hours, and then have to quit, and if you didn't use one of the toilets to quit then, congratulations! You just lost 6 hours of progress! The insulting thing about this is that the developer could put a functioning save system in the game, but he deliberately does not want to, because he knows about this, and he thinks it's hilarious that people playing his game will lose their progress like this.

Another example is the logistics of the game world; The player's house is at the opposite end of the map from all the stores you need, and the path that you have to take to get there is deliberately long. It will take you upwards of 20 - 30 IN REAL LIFE MINUTES to get to either the town or the repair store every time you need to go there. Your choices of transportation are a slow tractor, and a slower boat. You can't use your car until the late game. You MIGHT get a van, but the van takes upwards of 12 hours of real life gameplay to spawn, and it disappears randomly until several weeks of playing your in-game uncle gives it to you forever. This is another intentional design choice specifically aimed at frustrating and annoying players with no real benefit. This philosophy is best demonstrated by the developer's choice to make the player unable to move any items in bulk; you can't pick up more than one item, so 80% of your time spent playing the game is spent painstakingly taking 1 item at a time from place to place. This is especially bad when you try to use the boat to go grocery shopping; You have to take every individual item you purchased all the way from the grocery store on a 500 meter hike to the dock, put it in the boat, then go back to get the next item. 

The game has been deliberately filled with a lot of little things that together are only added to screw with the player. For example, the train crossings are all heavily obscured by bushes, so you can't actually see the train coming unless you stand on the tracks directly and look -- And if you stop on the tracks, the bad vehicle physics engine will immediately get your vehicle stuck on the tracks and cause your death. The game is also very dedicated to trying to kill your player with fire, as all the heat sources you can use for cooking take up to 5 IRL minutes (which is an hour in game) to get hot enough to start cooking. Yet despite these timeframes, if you look away from them they instantly burn your house down. 

While the car building segment of the game is entertaining, it itself has many large flaws which ultimately ruin the experience. There's no way to tell what the condition of a part is until it breaks, and a broken part is usually not identifiable as broken: The difference between a broken part and a fine one is that the broken one is a slightly darker shade. It's easier to tell when you have other parts to compare with, like the cylinders, but with other things it is impossible. What this means for your gameplay is that the engine will be broken when you build it, and there is no way of knowing why it's broken or what part needs to be replaced without using third party save editors made by modders to view your save file. Furthermore, many of the car attachment parts, such as the exhaust pipe, cannot be attached until you try twice, then restart your game, and then try a third time. And remember, if you didn't use the toilet to save and exit, you just lost your savegame as well! 

Really, the core problem of the game is that you need to perform a lot of different tasks ancillary to building the car before you can actually build it, and these tasks are all a long distance away, and your transportation options take an EXTREMELY long time to get anywhere. So you end up spending 40 minute IRL round trips getting things, frequently having to go back when you need something else for the car, or something goes wrong, etc. And if anything, ANYTHING goes wrong during any of these trips, you make a single mistake, or happen to have to step away from your computer during these trips, you INSTANTLY lose your entire save game and have to start again from the beginning. That's what's wrong with this game. 

And it's because the developer wants it to be like this. He could fix it, but everything I've described above is how he wants the game to be. Do not buy this game.

Well the dev decided to made his game "not fun" like he wanted to from the beginning, now he successfully made it, and too bad it's really not fun anymore. There was a radio system in the game that used to work really well, but now the portable radio needs 10 batteries and you need to change them every two hours ingame, and you can't buy even 10 batteries per week ingame, so no more music while repairing the car. And that's only one example. Also the fact that you have to go to groceries every day because food is being easily rotten. And the grinding for getting the car to the rally is a pain too.

TLDR : I'll play Mon Bazou instead, and I recommends everyone to do so.
